'0 - Arranging the Image'

1 - Click  to rotate the image.\nClick  to rotate the image.  It's the icon of a square with a curved arrow over its top-right corner at the top of the Preview window. This will rotate the image 90 degrees counter-clockwise.\n- Click the button as many times as you need to position the image to your liking.
2 - Click Tools.\nClick Tools. It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. This opens a drop-down menu with additional options.

3 - Select Flip Horizontal or Flip Vertical.\nSelect Flip Horizontal or Flip Vertical. It's near the bottom of the drop-down menu. Flipping the image horizontally will mirror the image from right to left, while flipping the image vertically will invert the picture from top to bottom, making the image appear upside down.\n- You can flip the image a second time to revert the image back to normal, or you can press ⌘ Command+Z to undo the last change.

'4 - Click .\nClick .  It\'s the Markup Toolbar" button that resembles a marker tip inside a circle, located at the top of the window. This will open the Markup Toolbar displaying the various editing tools.'
5 - Click .\nClick . It's the icon that has the dotted outline of a rectangle. This will open a small drop-down menu.

6 - Click Rectangular Selection.\nClick Rectangular Selection. It's the first option in the drop-down menu.\n- You can also click  to select the elliptical selection tool, or the lasso tool, which allows you to draw your own selection.

'7 - Click and drag the rectangle tool over the image.\nClick and drag the rectangle tool over the image.  The dotted line of the rectangle indicates how the image will be cropped.  Make sure the part of the image you want to keep are inside the rectangle marquee.\n- You can adjust the rectangle selection by clicking and dragging the blue dots (handles) in the corners of the rectangle.'
8 - Click Crop.\nClick Crop.  It's in the upper-right corner of the toolbar.  This will delete everything except for what's inside the rectangle selection.
'0 - Arranging the Image'

1 - Click  to rotate the image.\nClick  to rotate the image.  It's the icon of a square with a curved arrow over its top-right corner at the top of the Preview window. This will rotate the image 90 degrees counter-clockwise.\n- Click the button as many times as you need to position the image to your liking.
2 - Click Tools.\nClick Tools. It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. This opens a drop-down menu with additional options.

3 - Select Flip Horizontal or Flip Vertical.\nSelect Flip Horizontal or Flip Vertical. It's near the bottom of the drop-down menu. Flipping the image horizontally will mirror the image from right to left, while flipping the image vertically will invert the picture from top to bottom, making the image appear upside down.\n- You can flip the image a second time to revert the image back to normal, or you can press ⌘ Command+Z to undo the last change.

'4 - Click .\nClick .  It\'s the Markup Toolbar" button that resembles a marker tip inside a circle, located at the top of the window. This will open the Markup Toolbar displaying the various editing tools.'
5 - Click .\nClick . It's the icon that has the dotted outline of a rectangle. This will open a small drop-down menu.

6 - Click Rectangular Selection.\nClick Rectangular Selection. It's the first option in the drop-down menu.\n- You can also click  to select the elliptical selection tool, or the lasso tool, which allows you to draw your own selection.

'7 - Click and drag the rectangle tool over the image.\nClick and drag the rectangle tool over the image.  The dotted line of the rectangle indicates how the image will be cropped.  Make sure the part of the image you want to keep are inside the rectangle marquee.\n- You can adjust the rectangle selection by clicking and dragging the blue dots (handles) in the corners of the rectangle.'
8 - Click Crop.\nClick Crop.  It's in the upper-right corner of the toolbar.  This will delete everything except for what's inside the rectangle selection.
'0 - Adding Shapes to the Image'

1 - Click the shapes button.\nClick the shapes button.  It's the button that has a square and a circle.  This will display a drop-down menu with various shapes.  The shapes include a line, a rectangle, a rectangle with rounded images, an ellipse, a speech bubble, a star, and a hexagon.
'2 - Select a shape.\nSelect a shape.  This will generate the shape in the center of the image.'
'3 - Click and drag the shape.\nClick and drag the shape.  You can drag the shape to any location on the image.'
'4 - Adjust the size of the shape.\nAdjust the size of the shape.  Click and drag the blue dots (handles) in the corners of the shape to adjust the size of the shape'
'5 - Change shape color.\nChange shape color.  Click the solid colored rectangle in the toolbar and select a color.\n- The white box with a red line through it indicates no color.'

6 - Change outline color.\nChange outline color.  The outline is the line around the shape.  Click the button that has a thick line in the shape of a rectangle.  It's next to the solid colored rectangle button.  Select a color for the outline of the shape.\n- The white box with a red line through it indicates no outline.
'7 - Change thickness of outline.\nChange thickness of outline.  Click the button with three lines of different thicknesses and styles.'
'8 - Select a thickness.\nSelect a thickness.  There are seven line thicknesses to choose from.\n- You can also select different line styles, such as dotted lines, arrows, and textured lines.'
'0 - Adding Shapes to the Image'

1 - Click the shapes button.\nClick the shapes button.  It's the button that has a square and a circle.  This will display a drop-down menu with various shapes.  The shapes include a line, a rectangle, a rectangle with rounded images, an ellipse, a speech bubble, a star, and a hexagon.
'2 - Select a shape.\nSelect a shape.  This will generate the shape in the center of the image.'
'3 - Click and drag the shape.\nClick and drag the shape.  You can drag the shape to any location on the image.'
'4 - Adjust the size of the shape.\nAdjust the size of the shape.  Click and drag the blue dots (handles) in the corners of the shape to adjust the size of the shape'
'5 - Change shape color.\nChange shape color.  Click the solid colored rectangle in the toolbar and select a color.\n- The white box with a red line through it indicates no color.'

6 - Change outline color.\nChange outline color.  The outline is the line around the shape.  Click the button that has a thick line in the shape of a rectangle.  It's next to the solid colored rectangle button.  Select a color for the outline of the shape.\n- The white box with a red line through it indicates no outline.
'7 - Change thickness of outline.\nChange thickness of outline.  Click the button with three lines of different thicknesses and styles.'
'8 - Select a thickness.\nSelect a thickness.  There are seven line thicknesses to choose from.\n- You can also select different line styles, such as dotted lines, arrows, and textured lines.'
'0 - Troubleshooting Using Disk Utility on Mac'
1 - Open the Finder .\nOpen the Finder .  The Finder has a blue and white icon with a smiley face.  It's located in the dock at the bottom of the screen.
2 - Click Applications.\nClick Applications.  It's in the side bar to the left.  This displays all the applications installed on your Mac.
3 - Click Utilities.\nClick Utilities.  It's the blue folder in the Applications.  This displays all the utility programs for your Mac.

4 - Click the external hard drive volume.\nClick the external hard drive volume.  It's listed below the drive name in the sidebar to the left.  This displays how much of the external hard drive has been used.

'5 - Click Mount (if available).\nClick Mount (if available).  This button is at the top of the Disk Utility app.  This forces Mac OS to read the external hard drive.  If the button says "Unmount", the external hard drive is already mounted.  If the "Mount" button is grey out, Mac cannot read the disk.'

'6 - Click First Aid.\nClick First Aid.  If there is no volume for the external hard drive, or the mount button is greyed out, Mac cannot access the external hard drive.  Click "First Aid" at the top to scan the external hard drive for errors.'
'7 - Click Run.\nClick Run.  It\'s in the prompt that appears when you click "First Aid".  This runs a scan of the external hard drive and attempts to fix any errors.'

8 - Click Repair Disk.
Click Repair Disk.  If First Aid finds errors on the external hard drive, it display a list of the errors and ask if you want to repair the external hard drive.  Click Repair Disk to fix the errors on the external hard drive.  If First Aid is unable to repair the external hard drive, it may be formatted in a file system that MacOS can't read, or it may be a faulty external hard drive.[4]
- X
- Research source

'9 - Click Partition or Erase.
Click Partition or Erase.  If the external drive has be formatted using a file system that can't be read by MacOS, you could either partition the unused portion of the external hard drive, or erase the entire drive and reformat it in a file system that can be read by MacOS.  If you plan on only using the the external hard drive, select Mac OS Extended as the file system.  If you plan on using the external hard drive on other devices, select FAT32, or exFAT as the file system.  Warning:  Erasing and reformatting your external hard drive will erase all the contents on your external hard drive.  Use that as a last resort.  If possible, try to back up the contents of the external hard drive to another computer before reformatting it.  Use the following steps to partition or erase your external hard drive:
- 
- Partition:
- Click Partition in Disk Utility.
- Type a name for the partition next to "Name:.  
- Select a format for the partition next to "Format:".
- Type how much space you want to allocate to the partition next to "Size:".
- Click Apply.
- 
- 
- Erase:
- Click Erase in Disk Utility
- Type a name for the external hard drive next to "Name:"
- Select a file system next to "Format:"
- Click Erase'

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: 1 - Open the Finder .\nOpen the Finder .  The Finder has a blue and white icon with a smiley face.  It's located in the dock at the bottom of the screen.

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: 2 - Click Applications.\nClick Applications.  It's in the side bar to the left.  This displays all the applications installed on your Mac.

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: 3 - Click Utilities.\nClick Utilities.  It's the blue folder in the Applications.  This displays all the utility programs for your Mac.

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: 4 - Click the external hard drive volume.\nClick the external hard drive volume.  It's listed below the drive name in the sidebar to the left.  This displays how much of the external hard drive has been used.

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: '5 - Click Mount (if available).\nClick Mount (if available).  This button is at the top of the Disk Utility app.  This forces Mac OS to read the external hard drive.  If the button says "Unmount", the external hard drive is already mounted.  If the "Mount" button is grey out, Mac cannot read the disk.'

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: '6 - Click First Aid.\nClick First Aid.  If there is no volume for the external hard drive, or the mount button is greyed out, Mac cannot access the external hard drive.  Click "First Aid" at the top to scan the external hard drive for errors.'

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4: '7 - Click Run.\nClick Run.  It\'s in the prompt that appears when you click "First Aid".  This runs a scan of the external hard drive and attempts to fix any errors.'

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4:
8 - Click Repair Disk.
Click Repair Disk.  If First Aid finds errors on the external hard drive, it display a list of the errors and ask if you want to repair the external hard drive.  Click Repair Disk to fix the errors on the external hard drive.  If First Aid is unable to repair the external hard drive, it may be formatted in a file system that MacOS can't read, or it may be a faulty external hard drive.[4]
- X
- Research source

column1: 'Were settings of external hard drive volume changed?'
column4:
'9 - Click Partition or Erase.
Click Partition or Erase.  If the external drive has be formatted using a file system that can't be read by MacOS, you could either partition the unused portion of the external hard drive, or erase the entire drive and reformat it in a file system that can be read by MacOS.  If you plan on only using the the external hard drive, select Mac OS Extended as the file system.  If you plan on using the external hard drive on other devices, select FAT32, or exFAT as the file system.  Warning:  Erasing and reformatting your external hard drive will erase all the contents on your external hard drive.  Use that as a last resort.  If possible, try to back up the contents of the external hard drive to another computer before reformatting it.  Use the following steps to partition or erase your external hard drive:
- 
- Partition:
- Click Partition in Disk Utility.
- Type a name for the partition next to "Name:.  
- Select a format for the partition next to "Format:".
- Type how much space you want to allocate to the partition next to "Size:".
- Click Apply.
- 
- 
- Erase:
- Click Erase in Disk Utility
- Type a name for the external hard drive next to "Name:"
- Select a file system next to "Format:"
- Click Erase'
'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple icon.\nClick on the Apple icon. It's the Apple logo in the top left corner of the menu bar.\n- ;
'2 - Click System Preferences.\nClick System Preferences.'
'3 - Click the "Notifications" icon.\nClick the "Notifications" icon. It looks like a grey square with a red dot in one corner.'
4 - Click Calendar.\nClick Calendar. It's located in the list on the left side of the window.
'5 - Click on the "Show in Notification Center" check box.\nClick on the "Show in Notification Center" check box. It\'s on the right side of the Notifications window.'
'6 - Click the red "x" button.\nClick the red "x" button. Calendar will now be displayed in the Notification Center on your Mac.'
'0 - Steps'
'1 - Open the file you want to print.\nOpen the file you want to print. You can print anything in black-and-white, including color photos, even if you don’t see the option to do so in your app.\n- ;'
'2 - Click the File menu.\nClick the File menu. It’s in the menu bar at the top-left corner.'
'3 - Click Print.\nClick Print. A list of print settings will appear.'
'4 - Click Show Details.\nClick Show Details. Additional settings will appear.'

'5 - Check the box next to ″Black & White″ or print in grayscale.
Check the box next to ″Black & White″ or print in grayscale. If you don’t see the ″Black & White″ option, here’s how you can get the same effect:[1]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- Select Paper Type / Quality from the drop-down menu below ″Orientation.″
- Expand the Color Options menu by clicking it once.
- Select Grayscale from the ″Color″ drop-down menu.
- Select Black Ink Only under the ″Grayscale Mode″ header.'
'6 - Click Print.\nClick Print. It’s at the bottom-right corner of the window. The image or document will be sent to your printer in black-and-white or grayscale format.'

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: 1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: '2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: 3 - Click on Desktop & Screen Saver.\nClick on Desktop & Screen Saver. It's near the top of the preferences window.

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: 4 - Click on +.\nClick on +. It's beneath the pane on the left side of the dialog box that contains the list of folders and desktop pictures.

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: 5 - Click on the folder you'd like to use for background pictures.\nClick on the folder you'd like to use for background pictures.

column1: 'Were settings of folder you would like to use for background picture changed?'
column4: 6 - Click on Choose.\nClick on Choose. You've now added a folder from which you can choose background photos for your Mac.\n- To select a particular photo, click on the new folder -- it appears in the left pane of the dialog box, now -- and the select the individual image in the right pane of the box.
'0 - Turning on 24-Hour Time'
'1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu.\n- ;'
'2 - Click "System Preferences."\nClick "System Preferences." If you are not taken to the main System Preferences menu, click the "Show All" button at the top of the window.'
'3 - Click "Language & Region."\nClick "Language & Region." This icon can be found in the top row and has a flag for an icon.'
'4 - Click the "Time format" box.\nClick the "Time format" box. This will toggle between 24-hour time and 12-hour time.'
'5 - Click the "Region" menu to change your country.\nClick the "Region" menu to change your country. This will change your time and date formats automatically to match the country standard.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '0 - Creating a Custom Format'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '2 - Click "System Preferences."\nClick "System Preferences." You may already open to the "Language & Region" menu if you followed the previous method. If not, click the "Show All" button at the top of the window.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '3 - Click the "Language & Region" option.\nClick the "Language & Region" option. This will open your Mac\'s region settings.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '4 - Click the "Advanced" button.\nClick the "Advanced" button.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '5 - Click the "Times" tab.\nClick the "Times" tab.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '6 - Click and drag elements to customize the different formats.\nClick and drag elements to customize the different formats. These different lengths are used in different areas of the system.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '7 - Click the menu for each element to customize it.\nClick the menu for each element to customize it. This lets you select how the data is displayed. For example, clicking the minutes element can let you pick between "08" and "8" for the time.'

column1: 'Were settings of element to customize the different format changed?'
column4: '8 - Type custom labels for "AM" and "PM."\nType custom labels for "AM" and "PM." You can switch the before noon and after noon labels to whatever you\'d like.'

'0 - Changing Picture in Picture Zoom Options'
'1 - Click on the "Apple" icon in your menu bar, and select "System Preferences" from the menu.\nClick on the "Apple" icon in your menu bar, and select "System Preferences" from the menu.'
'2 - Click on the "Universal Access" icon.\nClick on the "Universal Access" icon.'
'3 - Click the "Options" button in the "Zoom" section.\nClick the "Options" button in the "Zoom" section.'
'4 - Adjust the magnification.\nAdjust the magnification. To do so, drag the top slider left or right.'

'5 - Play with zoom box placement.\nPlay with zoom box placement. If you would rather have a stationary zoom window (instead of one which moves with the cursor), press the button next to "Stationary."Alternatively, you can choose "Tiled along Edge." This will display the zoomed area along the left edge of your screen.'

'6 - Control where the window appears.\nControl where the window appears. If you choose the "Stationary" option, you can control where on your desktop the zoom window appears, as well as how much space it takes up. Click the "Adjust Size and Location" button, then drag the box that appears to your chosen place. You can change the size of the box by dragging the corners. Click the "OK" button when you are done.'

'7 - Decide on the look of your cursor.\nDecide on the look of your cursor. Click the "Crosshair" button if you would rather see a crosshair style cursor in the zoom window (instead of a normal mouse pointer).'
'8 - Invert colors.\nInvert colors. If you can read better with a black background, tick the "Invert Colors" box. This will invert all of the colors in the zoom box.'
'0 - Steps'

'1 - Back up your current data on your Mac using either the Time Machine or Carbon Copy Cloner programs.\nBack up your current data on your Mac using either the Time Machine or Carbon Copy Cloner programs.\n- ;'
'2 - Remove all external USB drives:\nRemove all external USB drives: external HDDs and flash sticks.'
'3 - Insert Mac OSX installation disk into your Mac.\nInsert Mac OSX installation disk into your Mac. Restart your computer.'

'4 - While Welcome Mac Music plays, press and hold "C" key on Mac keyboard to ensure your Mac will start from DVD drive.\nWhile Welcome Mac Music plays, press and hold "C" key on Mac keyboard to ensure your Mac will start from DVD drive.'
'5 - Wait till Mac OSX installation will load.\nWait till Mac OSX installation will load.'
'6 - Select your language and click "Next" button on the installation screen.\nSelect your language and click "Next" button on the installation screen.'
'7 - Accept the license terms.\nAccept the license terms.'

8 - Go to Utilities on the top menu and select Disk Utility.\nGo to Utilities on the top menu and select Disk Utility. The Disk Utility will start. On the top of left side of Disk Utility you will see your Mac's disk.

9 - Select that disk by clicking on it with mouse pointer.\nSelect that disk by clicking on it with mouse pointer. On the right side there will appear five tabs: 'First Aid', 'Erase', 'Partition', 'RAID', 'Restore'. Select the 'Partition' tab.

'10 - On the 'Partition' tab you will see "Volume Scheme'.
On the 'Partition' tab you will see "Volume Scheme'. It shows how many volumes your Mac's disk have. Normally, all Macs have just one volume and that is very big problem for the end user! Here's why: if your Mac crashes, it can happen that you will not be able to restore your private data (never forget Murphy's Law). It happens not so often compared with Windows, but when it happens you may lose your data forever: email settings, pictures, Garageband songs, iWork documents, iChat and calendar history, and so on. To avoid your data loss, it is recommended that you make two partitions on your Mac: one for OSX system, the other one for your private data.
- On that "Volume Scheme' select two partitions. Mac will divide the disk to two volumes, both of equal size.
- Move the slider up between the partitions. Leave 80 Gb of the disk capacity for the system and the rest for your files.'

11 - Click on that upper volume; that will be the OSX System volume.\nClick on that upper volume; that will be the OSX System volume.\n- On 'Volume Information' name your system disk like Mac, or Quark.
'12 - Select from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".'
'13 - Click the lower volume on the \'Volume Scheme".\nClick the lower volume on the \'Volume Scheme". Name your volume like "My safe box", "Data wardrobe", whatever you wish.'
'14 - Select from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".'

'15 - Until this moment you still have your data on your Mac.\nUntil this moment you still have your data on your Mac. Are you sure you backed up your data? If 100% YES, then... click "Apply" button. The Disk Utility will ask something like "if you will proceed you will lose all your data", click OK. You will lose your data for sure.'

'16 - Wait until formatting has ended.\nWait until formatting has ended. When it ends, on the left side of the Disk Utility you will see now two empty new volumes: the upper one is for system, the lower one for your data.'
'17 - If everything is OK, Select "Disk Utility" on the top menu and click "Quit Disk Utility".\nIf everything is OK, Select "Disk Utility" on the top menu and click "Quit Disk Utility".'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: 9 - Select that disk by clicking on it with mouse pointer.\nSelect that disk by clicking on it with mouse pointer. On the right side there will appear five tabs: 'First Aid', 'Erase', 'Partition', 'RAID', 'Restore'. Select the 'Partition' tab.

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4:
'10 - On the 'Partition' tab you will see "Volume Scheme'.
On the 'Partition' tab you will see "Volume Scheme'. It shows how many volumes your Mac's disk have. Normally, all Macs have just one volume and that is very big problem for the end user! Here's why: if your Mac crashes, it can happen that you will not be able to restore your private data (never forget Murphy's Law). It happens not so often compared with Windows, but when it happens you may lose your data forever: email settings, pictures, Garageband songs, iWork documents, iChat and calendar history, and so on. To avoid your data loss, it is recommended that you make two partitions on your Mac: one for OSX system, the other one for your private data.
- On that "Volume Scheme' select two partitions. Mac will divide the disk to two volumes, both of equal size.
- Move the slider up between the partitions. Leave 80 Gb of the disk capacity for the system and the rest for your files.'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: 11 - Click on that upper volume; that will be the OSX System volume.\nClick on that upper volume; that will be the OSX System volume.\n- On 'Volume Information' name your system disk like Mac, or Quark.

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: '12 - Select from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: '13 - Click the lower volume on the \'Volume Scheme".\nClick the lower volume on the \'Volume Scheme". Name your volume like "My safe box", "Data wardrobe", whatever you wish.'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: '14 - Select from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: '15 - Until this moment you still have your data on your Mac.\nUntil this moment you still have your data on your Mac. Are you sure you backed up your data? If 100% YES, then... click "Apply" button. The Disk Utility will ask something like "if you will proceed you will lose all your data", click OK. You will lose your data for sure.'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: '16 - Wait until formatting has ended.\nWait until formatting has ended. When it ends, on the left side of the Disk Utility you will see now two empty new volumes: the upper one is for system, the lower one for your data.'

column1: 'Were settings of format drop - down menu " mac os extend ( journaled ) changed?'
column4: '17 - If everything is OK, Select "Disk Utility" on the top menu and click "Quit Disk Utility".\nIf everything is OK, Select "Disk Utility" on the top menu and click "Quit Disk Utility".'
'0 - Steps'

'1 - Back up your current data on your Mac using either the Time Machine or Carbon Copy Cloner programs.\nBack up your current data on your Mac using either the Time Machine or Carbon Copy Cloner programs.\n- ;'
'2 - Remove all external USB drives:\nRemove all external USB drives: external HDDs and flash sticks.'
'3 - Insert Mac OSX installation disk into your Mac.\nInsert Mac OSX installation disk into your Mac. Restart your computer.'

'4 - While Welcome Mac Music plays, press and hold "C" key on Mac keyboard to ensure your Mac will start from DVD drive.\nWhile Welcome Mac Music plays, press and hold "C" key on Mac keyboard to ensure your Mac will start from DVD drive.'
'5 - Wait till Mac OSX installation will load.\nWait till Mac OSX installation will load.'
'6 - Select your language and click "Next" button on the installation screen.\nSelect your language and click "Next" button on the installation screen.'
'7 - Accept the license terms.\nAccept the license terms.'

8 - Go to Utilities on the top menu and select Disk Utility.\nGo to Utilities on the top menu and select Disk Utility. The Disk Utility will start. On the top of left side of Disk Utility you will see your Mac's disk.

9 - Select that disk by clicking on it with mouse pointer.\nSelect that disk by clicking on it with mouse pointer. On the right side there will appear five tabs: 'First Aid', 'Erase', 'Partition', 'RAID', 'Restore'. Select the 'Partition' tab.

'10 - On the 'Partition' tab you will see "Volume Scheme'.
On the 'Partition' tab you will see "Volume Scheme'. It shows how many volumes your Mac's disk have. Normally, all Macs have just one volume and that is very big problem for the end user! Here's why: if your Mac crashes, it can happen that you will not be able to restore your private data (never forget Murphy's Law). It happens not so often compared with Windows, but when it happens you may lose your data forever: email settings, pictures, Garageband songs, iWork documents, iChat and calendar history, and so on. To avoid your data loss, it is recommended that you make two partitions on your Mac: one for OSX system, the other one for your private data.
- On that "Volume Scheme' select two partitions. Mac will divide the disk to two volumes, both of equal size.
- Move the slider up between the partitions. Leave 80 Gb of the disk capacity for the system and the rest for your files.'

11 - Click on that upper volume; that will be the OSX System volume.\nClick on that upper volume; that will be the OSX System volume.\n- On 'Volume Information' name your system disk like Mac, or Quark.
'12 - Select from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".'
'13 - Click the lower volume on the \'Volume Scheme".\nClick the lower volume on the \'Volume Scheme". Name your volume like "My safe box", "Data wardrobe", whatever you wish.'
'14 - Select from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect from Format drop-down menu "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".'

'15 - Until this moment you still have your data on your Mac.\nUntil this moment you still have your data on your Mac. Are you sure you backed up your data? If 100% YES, then... click "Apply" button. The Disk Utility will ask something like "if you will proceed you will lose all your data", click OK. You will lose your data for sure.'

'16 - Wait until formatting has ended.\nWait until formatting has ended. When it ends, on the left side of the Disk Utility you will see now two empty new volumes: the upper one is for system, the lower one for your data.'
'17 - If everything is OK, Select "Disk Utility" on the top menu and click "Quit Disk Utility".\nIf everything is OK, Select "Disk Utility" on the top menu and click "Quit Disk Utility".'

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: '1 - Click .\nClick . Click the Apple menu in the upper-left corner of the menu bar.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: 2 - Click Shut Down….\nClick Shut Down…. It's near the bottom of the Apple Menu. This will open a pop-up window.

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: 3 - Click Shut Down to confirm.\nClick Shut Down to confirm. It's in the bottom-right corner of the pop-up window.

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: '4 - Press the power button on your Mac.\nPress the power button on your Mac.  The power button is located behind the monitor on the left side or iMacs, and on the keyboard of MacBooks.'

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: '5 - Immediately press and hold ⌘ Command+⌥ Option+P+R.\nImmediately press and hold ⌘ Command+⌥ Option+P+R.  Press these four buttons immediately after powering up and hold them while the computer boots up.'

column1: 'Were settings of shut down to changed?'
column4: '6 - Release ⌘ Command+⌥ Option+P+R after you hear the startup chime a second time.\nRelease ⌘ Command+⌥ Option+P+R after you hear the startup chime a second time.  Allow your Mac to boot up. You will have the option to check the startup disk, date and time, display resolution, and change the sounds.'
'0 - Getting macOS Sierra'

'1 - Go to http:__beta.apple.com_sp_betaprogram_.\nGo to http://beta.apple.com/sp/betaprogram/. As of August, 2016, macOS Sierra is only available to the public in its beta version. You can download that version from the Apple website.\n- ;'
'2 - Click "Sign Up".\nClick "Sign Up". You\'ll be brought to a login page.'
'3 - Log in with your Apple ID.\nLog in with your Apple ID. Enter your Apple ID and Password. Then, click'
'4 - Accept the terms of agreement.\nAccept the terms of agreement. Read the licensing agreement that appears on your screen, scroll to the bottom of the page, and click "Accept."'

5 - Copy your redeem code.\nCopy your redeem code. Although the download will begin automatically, you'll also be shown a code that you can use as proof of your entitlement to the beta software. Copy this code so that it's safe, just in case.\n- To copy the cody, click and drag your mouse over it so it highlights blue. Then, press command+c.
'6 - Click "Download the macOS Sierra Public Beta.\nClick "Download the macOS Sierra Public Beta."'

'7 - Open the App Store.\nOpen the App Store. On your Mac, click on the magnifying glass in the top-right corner of your screen to open Spotlight\'s search function. Type "App Store" into the search bar, and click on the "App Store" result.'
'8 - Click on the "Featured" tab at the top of the window.\nClick on the "Featured" tab at the top of the window.'
'9 - Click "Redeem" in the sidebar on the right.\nClick "Redeem" in the sidebar on the right.'

'10 - Enter your Redeem code.\nEnter your Redeem code. Hit enter when you are done, and the download will begin automatically.\n- Given that macOS Sierra is a large program, it may take a number of hours to download. You can check the progress of the download by opening the application "Launchpad" in your Finder.'

'11 - Open Launchpad.\nOpen Launchpad. When the download is complete, use Spotlight to search for and open the application called "Launchpad". In your Launchpad, you\'ll now see an icon labelled macOS Sierra.'
'12 - Click "Install" to launch the macOS Sierra Public Beta app.\nClick "Install" to launch the macOS Sierra Public Beta app. Then, click "Continue" on the window that appears.'

13 - Backup your computer.\nBackup your computer. If you haven't backed up your computer recently, click Continue in the dropdown menu that appears. If you have recently backed up your computer or don't care to, click Cancel.
'14 - Accept the licensing terms.\nAccept the licensing terms. Click "Accept" at the bottom of the window that appears to do so. Click "Agree" again to confirm the download.'
'15 - Click Install.\nClick Install. The installation will default to your Macintosh hard drive.'
'16 - Enter your administrator password and click OK.\nEnter your administrator password and click OK.'
'17 - Restart your computer.\nRestart your computer. The update will occur while the computer is restarting.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '1 - Open your web browser of choice.\nOpen your web browser of choice.\n- PiP is also usable in iTunes.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '2 - Navigate to a video you would like to watch.\nNavigate to a video you would like to watch. YouTube and Vimeo are both popular video streaming sites.\n- Some video streaming sites may not support Picture-in-Picture.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '3 - Hold control and double-click on the video.\nHold control and double-click on the video. This will reveal a drop-down menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '4 - Click "Enter Picture-in-Picture".\nClick "Enter Picture-in-Picture". Clicking on this icon will enable Picture-in-Picture, causing the video you\'re watching to open in a new, smaller window.\n- Some video players such as Vimeo will have a Picture-in-Picture icon built into the window. This is an icon at the bottom-right corner of the video window that displays as a white rectangle "popping out" of another rectangular frame. Clicking on this icon will enable Picture-in-Picture.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '5 - Open a new application.\nOpen a new application. Click on an application in your dock or double-click on an application in your finder to open a new application. The video window will remain in the front of the screen.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '6 - Change your desktop window.\nChange your desktop window. Swipe three fingers to the left or right on your trackpad to navigate to a different desktop view. You will notice that the video still remains at the front of your screen.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4: '7 - Click and drag an edge of the video window to resize it.\nClick and drag an edge of the video window to resize it.'

column1: 'Were settings of enter picture - in - picture changed?'
column4:
8 - Click on the window to view basic options.
Click on the window to view basic options. By clicking on the video's pop-out window, you'll see three new options:
- A close window button in the upper-left corner.
- A pause/play button at the bottom of the window.
- An Exit PiP button next to the pause/play button, which will send the video back to your web browser to continue being played.
'1 - Open your web browser of choice.\nOpen your web browser of choice.\n- PiP is also usable in iTunes.'

'2 - Navigate to a video you would like to watch.\nNavigate to a video you would like to watch. YouTube and Vimeo are both popular video streaming sites.\n- Some video streaming sites may not support Picture-in-Picture.'
'3 - Hold control and double-click on the video.\nHold control and double-click on the video. This will reveal a drop-down menu.'

'4 - Click "Enter Picture-in-Picture".\nClick "Enter Picture-in-Picture". Clicking on this icon will enable Picture-in-Picture, causing the video you\'re watching to open in a new, smaller window.\n- Some video players such as Vimeo will have a Picture-in-Picture icon built into the window. This is an icon at the bottom-right corner of the video window that displays as a white rectangle "popping out" of another rectangular frame. Clicking on this icon will enable Picture-in-Picture.'

'5 - Open a new application.\nOpen a new application. Click on an application in your dock or double-click on an application in your finder to open a new application. The video window will remain in the front of the screen.'

'6 - Change your desktop window.\nChange your desktop window. Swipe three fingers to the left or right on your trackpad to navigate to a different desktop view. You will notice that the video still remains at the front of your screen.'
'7 - Click and drag an edge of the video window to resize it.\nClick and drag an edge of the video window to resize it.'

8 - Click on the window to view basic options.
Click on the window to view basic options. By clicking on the video's pop-out window, you'll see three new options:
- A close window button in the upper-left corner.
- A pause/play button at the bottom of the window.
- An Exit PiP button next to the pause/play button, which will send the video back to your web browser to continue being played.
'0 - Setting Up'
'1 - Select the VirtualBox icon to open the program.\nSelect the VirtualBox icon to open the program.'
'2 - Click the “New” button.\nClick the “New” button. \xa0Select the type as “Linux.” \xa0Type your name and select the Ubuntu (64 bit) option. \xa0Next, click “Continue.”'

'3 - Select the 512 MB memory size for everyday use.\nSelect the 512 MB memory size for everyday use. \xa0If you plan on downloading additional applications within the machine, select 2048 MB. \xa0For large projects, select 4096 MB. \xa0Click “Continue.”'
'4 - On the next page, select the “Create a virtual hard drive now” radio button.\nOn the next page, select the “Create a virtual hard drive now” radio button. \xa0Select “Create.”'
'5 - Select the “VDI (VirtualBox Disk Image)” option as the hard drive file type.\nSelect the “VDI (VirtualBox Disk Image)” option as the hard drive file type. \xa0Click “Continue.”'

'6 - On the “Storage and physical hard drive” page, leave the option on “Dynamically Allocated” and click “Continue.\nOn the “Storage and physical hard drive” page, leave the option on “Dynamically Allocated” and click “Continue.”'

'7 - To choose the file location and size, type in the name of the new virtual hard drive and keep the 8 GB option.\nTo choose the file location and size, type in the name of the new virtual hard drive and keep the 8 GB option.'
'8 - Select the name of the machine that you just created, and then click the green “Start” arrow.\nSelect the name of the machine that you just created, and then click the green “Start” arrow.'
'9 - On the next page, click the yellow folder icon.\nOn the next page, click the yellow folder icon.'
'10 - Search for the .iso file that you downloaded previously.\nSearch for the .iso file that you downloaded previously. \xa0Open the file.'
'11 - Click on “Install Ubuntu.\nClick on “Install Ubuntu.”'

'12 - Do not select either of the two options to “Download updates while installing” and “Install this third-party software.\nDo not select either of the two options to “Download updates while installing” and “Install this third-party software.” Click “Continue.”'
'13 - Make sure “Erase disk and install Ubuntu” is selected.\nMake sure “Erase disk and install Ubuntu” is selected. \xa0Click “Continue.”'

'14 - Follow instructions to select the region where you live, language preferences, and your username and password.\nFollow instructions to select the region where you live, language preferences, and your username and password. \xa0Finally, select “Log in later.” The computer will now install the Ubuntu Operating System. \xa0This process could take up to 20 minutes, but requires no effort on your part. \xa0When it is done you will have a fully-function Ubuntu Virtual Machine.'

'0 - Installing macOS Sierra'

'1 - Consider backing up your computer.\nConsider backing up your computer. Before installing a brand-new operating system on your Mac, you may want to back up your files; failure to do so could result in losing your files in the event of an error.\n- ;'

'2 - Open your Mac's App Store.
Open your Mac's App Store. You'll find the App Store icon--a white stylized "A" on a blue background--in your dock. MacOS Sierra is free to download and install from the Apple App Store for Mac OS X users who meet the following criteria:[1]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- Your Mac must be from 2009 or later.
- Your Mac must be running the Yosemite, Mavericks, or El Capitan version of OS X (if it isn't, you'll need to upgrade before you can install macOS).
- Your Mac must have at least 2 gigabytes of RAM.
- Your Mac must have at least 10 gigabytes of free hard drive space to accommodate the download.'

'3 - Type "macOS Sierra" into the App Store\'s search bar.\nType "macOS Sierra" into the App Store\'s search bar. The search bar should be in the top right corner of your App Store\'s window.\n- You may also see a link to macOS Sierra in the "Quick Links" section on the right side of your screen, or an "Upgrade Now" banner at the top of the screen. You can click either of these to expedite your process.'

'4 - Click the "Get" button at the top of your screen.
Click the "Get" button at the top of your screen. This will begin the download process; you'll need to follow your Mac's on-screen instructions to initiate the download itself.[2]
- X
- Research source
- 
- You may have to enter your Apple ID and the relevant password in order to begin your download.'
'5 - Wait for your macOS Sierra download to complete.\nWait for your macOS Sierra download to complete. Once it does, you should see an installer window pop up.'
6 - Follow the installer's instructions.\nFollow the installer's instructions. You'll need to agree to Apple's Terms and Conditions before you can officially install macOS Sierra.

'7 - Click "Install" to begin the macOS installation.\nClick "Install" to begin the macOS installation. The installation will default to your Macintosh hard drive.\n- You may have to enter your computer\'s Administrator password to finalize this process.'

'8 - Enable Siri.\nEnable Siri. After installing macOS Sierra, you will be asked whether or not you want to enable Siri. Check "Enable Siri on this Mac" and hit continue. Now you\'ll be able to use Siri right from your desktop!'
'0 - Using a Different Browser'

1 - Open the site in another browser.\nOpen the site in another browser. Most likely, Safari won't load a page because it doesn't meet the security standards of macOS 10.10.4 and iOS 8.4. You can use another browser to unlock these sites for Safari so you can access them with the default browser.

2 - Click the lock icon in the address bar.\nClick the lock icon in the address bar. Once the page loads in the other browser, such as Firefox, you'll see a small green lock icon next to the URL address. When you click that, a menu will pop-up.

'3 - Click the arrow to expand more information .
Click the arrow to expand more information . This will bring up more information and options for the site security.[4]
- X
- Research source'
4 - Click More information.\nClick More information. You'll see this at the bottom of the pop-up menu.
'5 - Click View Certificate.\nClick View Certificate. This is on the Security tab, in the top section.'
6 - Click the Details tab.\nClick the Details tab. You'll find this near the top of the page with General.\n- You'll see the information you need to allow Safari to connect to this site on this tab.
'7 - Open Keychain.\nOpen Keychain. You can either press Cmd + Spacebar and search for keychain in Spotlight or you can open the program from Finder > Applications > Utilities.'
'8 - Click System Roots.\nClick System Roots. You\'ll see this in the column on the left side of the window under "Keychains."'

'9 - Find the entry that is blocked by Safari.\nFind the entry that is blocked by Safari. You\'ll see this certificate information in the "Details" page of the website. It\'s usually listed as "Issued by…".\n- For example, if Facebook is blocked by Safari, you\'ll see in the "Details" page of the website "Issued by: DigiCert SHA2 High Assurance CA," which you should find in your Keychain as well.'
10 - Double-click the entry.\nDouble-click the entry. It'll open in a new window.
'11 - Click the arrow next to "Trust" to expand it .\nClick the arrow next to "Trust" to expand it . You\'ll see a bunch of options load.'

'12 - Select Use System Defaults next to "When using this certificate.\nSelect Use System Defaults next to "When using this certificate." You don\'t want to use your system\'s defaults because that\'ll end up blocking that page from loading.'
'13 - Select "Always Trust" from the drop-down.\nSelect "Always Trust" from the drop-down. This setting allows this page to always load with Safari. You\'ll see all the other options change as well.'
14 - Close all the windows you have open and try the website on Safari.\nClose all the windows you have open and try the website on Safari. If it still doesn't load, continue to the next method.

2 - Click the lock icon in the address bar.\nClick the lock icon in the address bar. Once the page loads in the other browser, such as Firefox, you'll see a small green lock icon next to the URL address. When you click that, a menu will pop-up.

column1: 'Were settings of select you name changed?'
column4: '1 - Click on the  apple in the top left corner of the screen.\nClick on the  apple in the top left corner of the screen.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of select you name changed?'
column4: '2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.\n- You can also find  System Preferences in your dock.'

column1: 'Were settings of select you name changed?'
column4: '3 - Click on Users & Groups.\nClick on Users & Groups. The icon has a silhouette of two people.'

column1: 'Were settings of select you name changed?'
column4: '4 - Select your name from the Current User list.\nSelect your name from the Current User list.'

column1: 'Were settings of select you name changed?'
column4: '5 - Click on the Login Items tab.\nClick on the Login Items tab. You will get a list of programs that open automatically when you log in.'

column1: 'Were settings of select you name changed?'
column4: 6 - Uncheck any programs that you don't need when your Mac starts up.\nUncheck any programs that you don't need when your Mac starts up. Fewer programs at startup will help your Mac launch faster and will not hog up your computer's resources in the background.
'0 - Using Terminal Commands'

'1 - Add a message to your login screen.
Add a message to your login screen. You can add a message to your login screen by typing:
- 
- sudo defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow LoginwindowText "If this laptop is lost, please call 555-555-5555. Cash reward."
- 
- Then press ⏎ Return. Replace the message in the quotation marks with a message of your own. This will display this text in your login screen at startup.'

'2 - Add blank spaces to your dock.
Add blank spaces to your dock. You can add blank spaces to the application dock by typing:
- 
- defaults write com.apple.dock persistent-apps -array-add '{"tile-type"="spacer-tile";}'
- killall Dock
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. This will add a blank space to the dock each time you enter this command. You can click and drag the space to move it around in the dock, creating a divider for organization.
- If you're prompted to enter your password, type your password and press ⏎ Return.
- To delete a blank space from the dock, simply drag the space out of the dock until it says "Remove" then let it go.[1]
- X
- Research source'

'3 - Prevent your Mac from going to sleep.
Prevent your Mac from going to sleep. To prevent your Mac from going to sleep, simply type:
- 
- caffeinate
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. This will keep the Mac from going to sleep or logging you out from inactivity.
- To allow the Mac to sleep again, press Control+C into Terminal to end the "caffeinate" task.'

'4 - Hide a Folder.
Hide a Folder. If you created a folder on your desktop called "HiddenFolder", and your Mac username was "Steve", you could hide that folder by typing:
- 
- chflags hidden "/Users/Steve/Desktop/HiddenFolder"
- 
- Then press ⏎ Return. Replace "Steve" with your own username and replace "HiddenFolder" with your folder's name.
- You can also just type chflags hidden then drag and drop your folder directly\xa0 into the Terminal window, then press ⏎ Return.
- On the Desktop or in any Finder window, you can toggle between showing and not-showing hidden files by pressing ⌘ Command+⇧ Shift+..'

'5 - Unhide a folder.
Unhide a folder. To unhide the same folder in the previous step, you would type:
- 
- chflags nohidden "/Users/Steve/Desktop/HiddenFolder"
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. This will make the folder a normal folder that is always shown.'

'6 - Change the location of your screenshots.
Change the location of your screenshots. By default, screenshots are saved directly on the Desktop. So if you wanted the screenshots to be saved in a folder on the Desktop called "Screenshots" you would type:
- 
- defaults write com.apple.screencapture location "/Users/Steve/Desktop/Screenshots"
- killall SystemUIServer
- 
- Then press ⏎ Return. Replace "Steve" with your own username and replace "Screenshots" with the folder name you created.
- You'll need to create the folder first for this will work properly\xa0, otherwise the screenshots will end up on the desktop by default.'

'7 - Add a recent or favorite items stack to the dock.
Add a recent or favorite items stack to the dock. You can add a recent or favorite items stack that you can customize in your dock by typing: 
- 
- defaults write com.apple.dock persistent-others -array-add '{ "tile-data" = { "list-type" = 1; }; "tile-type" = "recents-tile"; }'; killall Dock
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. The new stack will appear next to the trash can. You can then right-click (Control+click) to change the stack to be recent applications, documents, servers, or even favorite volumes or items. 
- To remove the stack from the dock, right-click (Control+click) and select "Remove from Dock".'

'8 - Disable the Dashboard completely.
Disable the Dashboard completely. If you don't use the dashboard on your Mac and don't want it to use of any system resources, you can turn it off entirely by typing:
- 
- defaults write com.apple.dashboard mcx-disabled -boolean yes; killall Dock
- 
- Press ⏎ Return.
- To re-enable the Dashboard, you can repeat the same command but change the "yes" to "no".'
'0 - Using Terminal Commands'

'1 - Add a message to your login screen.
Add a message to your login screen. You can add a message to your login screen by typing:
- 
- sudo defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow LoginwindowText "If this laptop is lost, please call 555-555-5555. Cash reward."
- 
- Then press ⏎ Return. Replace the message in the quotation marks with a message of your own. This will display this text in your login screen at startup.'

'2 - Add blank spaces to your dock.
Add blank spaces to your dock. You can add blank spaces to the application dock by typing:
- 
- defaults write com.apple.dock persistent-apps -array-add '{"tile-type"="spacer-tile";}'
- killall Dock
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. This will add a blank space to the dock each time you enter this command. You can click and drag the space to move it around in the dock, creating a divider for organization.
- If you're prompted to enter your password, type your password and press ⏎ Return.
- To delete a blank space from the dock, simply drag the space out of the dock until it says "Remove" then let it go.[1]
- X
- Research source'

'3 - Prevent your Mac from going to sleep.
Prevent your Mac from going to sleep. To prevent your Mac from going to sleep, simply type:
- 
- caffeinate
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. This will keep the Mac from going to sleep or logging you out from inactivity.
- To allow the Mac to sleep again, press Control+C into Terminal to end the "caffeinate" task.'

'4 - Hide a Folder.
Hide a Folder. If you created a folder on your desktop called "HiddenFolder", and your Mac username was "Steve", you could hide that folder by typing:
- 
- chflags hidden "/Users/Steve/Desktop/HiddenFolder"
- 
- Then press ⏎ Return. Replace "Steve" with your own username and replace "HiddenFolder" with your folder's name.
- You can also just type chflags hidden then drag and drop your folder directly\xa0 into the Terminal window, then press ⏎ Return.
- On the Desktop or in any Finder window, you can toggle between showing and not-showing hidden files by pressing ⌘ Command+⇧ Shift+..'

'5 - Unhide a folder.
Unhide a folder. To unhide the same folder in the previous step, you would type:
- 
- chflags nohidden "/Users/Steve/Desktop/HiddenFolder"
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. This will make the folder a normal folder that is always shown.'

'6 - Change the location of your screenshots.
Change the location of your screenshots. By default, screenshots are saved directly on the Desktop. So if you wanted the screenshots to be saved in a folder on the Desktop called "Screenshots" you would type:
- 
- defaults write com.apple.screencapture location "/Users/Steve/Desktop/Screenshots"
- killall SystemUIServer
- 
- Then press ⏎ Return. Replace "Steve" with your own username and replace "Screenshots" with the folder name you created.
- You'll need to create the folder first for this will work properly\xa0, otherwise the screenshots will end up on the desktop by default.'

'7 - Add a recent or favorite items stack to the dock.
Add a recent or favorite items stack to the dock. You can add a recent or favorite items stack that you can customize in your dock by typing: 
- 
- defaults write com.apple.dock persistent-others -array-add '{ "tile-data" = { "list-type" = 1; }; "tile-type" = "recents-tile"; }'; killall Dock
- 
- Press ⏎ Return. The new stack will appear next to the trash can. You can then right-click (Control+click) to change the stack to be recent applications, documents, servers, or even favorite volumes or items. 
- To remove the stack from the dock, right-click (Control+click) and select "Remove from Dock".'

'8 - Disable the Dashboard completely.
Disable the Dashboard completely. If you don't use the dashboard on your Mac and don't want it to use of any system resources, you can turn it off entirely by typing:
- 
- defaults write com.apple.dashboard mcx-disabled -boolean yes; killall Dock
- 
- Press ⏎ Return.
- To re-enable the Dashboard, you can repeat the same command but change the "yes" to "no".'

'1 - Restart your Mac.\nRestart your Mac. When your Mac begins its startup process, hold down the "Command" and "R" keys.\n- ;'

'2 - Open Terminal.
Open Terminal.
- Click "Utilities" in the menu bar.
- Select "Terminal".'
'3 - Type "reset password" into Terminal and hit "Enter".\nType "reset password" into Terminal and hit "Enter". This will result in a reset password tool popping up.'

4 - Select your computer's hard drive.\nSelect your computer's hard drive. In some isolated cases your computer's hard drive may not show up. This occurs if your hard drive is encrypted and can't be modified with this password tool.
'5 - Choose a user to reset.\nChoose a user to reset.'
6 - Enter a new password.\nEnter a new password. This will become your user's master password, so be sure to remember your change.
'7 - Click Save.\nClick Save. After clicking save, nothing major will happen. The password fields in the form will go blank. Just go ahead and proceed to the next step.'
'8 - Restart your Mac.\nRestart your Mac. When your Mac boots, you should be able to log in to the user you forgot the password for.'

- For 10.4 or later, click "Utilities" in the menu and select "Reset Password".

'1 - Open the Apple Menu.\nOpen the Apple Menu. Do so by clicking on the apple icon in the upper-left corner of the screen.\n- ;'

4 - Click on General.\nClick on General. It's a tab at the top of the dialog box.
5 - Click the padlock icon.\nClick the padlock icon. It's in the lower-left corner of the dialog box.
6 - Enter an admin username and password.\nEnter an admin username and password. If you haven't set a password for your Mac, follow these instructions to do so.
'7 - Check "Require password."\nCheck "Require password." It\'s near the top of the dialog box.'
'8 - Click on the drop-down menu next to "Require password."\nClick on the drop-down menu next to "Require password."'
9 - Click on immediately.\nClick on immediately. It's the first option in the drop-down menu.
10 - Click on the Apple Menu.\nClick on the Apple Menu. It's in the upper-left corner of screen.

11 - Click on Sleep.\nClick on Sleep. It's near the bottom of the drop-down menu. Your Mac will go to sleep and you'll have to enter your password to access it again.\n- You'll also have to log-in with your password anytime you power on or restart your Mac.

6 - Click on Preferences.\nClick on Preferences. It's near the top of the drop-down menu.

'0 - Changing Your DNS Settings'

'1 - Unplug your modem (and router, if you have one) for a few seconds.
Unplug your modem (and router, if you have one) for a few seconds. Doing so will force your modem through a power cycle and might fix some DNS issues.
- Many modern modems are also a router, but if you have a separate router, make sure you unplug that as well to ensure the DNS settings are reset.
- Wait for about 30 seconds until you plug in your router and modem.
- ;'
2 - Open System Preferences.\nOpen System Preferences. You'll find this inside the Apple menu at the top left of your screen.
'3 - Click Network.\nClick Network. This is usually in the third row from the top with "iCloud."'
4 - Click Advanced.\nClick Advanced. You'll find this in the lower right corner of the pop-up window.
5 - Click the DNS tab.\nClick the DNS tab. You'll see this along with tabs for Wi-Fi and Hardware.

'6 - Delete the existing entries in the box on the left.
Delete the existing entries in the box on the left. You can do this by clicking them to select them and then clicking the minus icon (-) below the box.[2]
- X
- Research source'

'7 - Add the two Google DNS addresses.
Add the two Google DNS addresses. Do this by clicking the plus icon (+) below the box and enter 8.8.8.8.[3]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- Click the plus icon (+) again and enter 8.8.4.4.
- Click OK to proceed.'
8 - Click Apply.\nClick Apply. You'll find this in the bottom right corner of the Network window.
9 - Restart your computer.\nRestart your computer. After your computer restarts, try the website again. If it still won't load, continue through the next method.
'0 - Changing Number Format for the Keyboard'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
3 - Click on Keyboard.\nClick on Keyboard. It's near the center of the preferences window.\n- If you don't see all of the System Preferences icons, click on ⋮⋮⋮⋮ in the top bar of the dialog box.
4 - Click on Input Sources.\nClick on Input Sources. It's near the top of the dialog box.
5 - Click on +.\nClick on +. It's below the pane on the left side of the dialog box.
6 - Click on a number_language format.\nClick on a number/language format. They're listed alphabetically by language in the left pane of the dialog box.

'7 - Click on Add.\nClick on Add. You\'ve now changed the number format to that of the corresponding language. For example, if you select Bengali, the number keys will display Bengali characters.\n- Check the box next to "Show input menu in menu bar," at the bottom of the dialog box, so you can toggle between number formats and keyboard languages.'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4: '0 - Using Tabs'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4:
'1 - Open an application on your Mac.
Open an application on your Mac. Tabs in macOS Sierra work on all web browsers (Safari, Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge), but they now also work in several other Apple and third-party apps. Some apps that you can open to use tabs on macOS Sierra include:
- Mail
- Maps
- TextEdit
- Keynote
- Numbers
- Pages
- Microsoft Word
- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4: '2 - Press ⌘ Command+T to open a new tab.\nPress ⌘ Command+T to open a new tab. The tab will open to the right of your first tab, just underneath the window\'s options.\n- On a web browser, you can also click on the "+" button in the upper-right corner of the window.'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4: 3 - Press ⌘ Command+N to open a new window.\nPress ⌘ Command+N to open a new window. This time, a new window will open on top of the current one you're working in.

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4: '4 - Press ⌘ Command+W to close a window.\nPress ⌘ Command+W to close a window. The window you currently have open at the front of your screen will close.'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4: '5 - Click on a tab at the top of the window.\nClick on a tab at the top of the window. The slightly brighter tab indicates your current tab. To navigate between tabs, click on a tab that displays as darker.'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4: '6 - Drag a tab out of its current window to create a new one.\nDrag a tab out of its current window to create a new one. If you would like to separate your tabs by having different windows to work in, you can click and hold your mouse over a particular tab and drag it off onto your desktop to create a new window.'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4:
'7 - Merge all of your windows.
Merge all of your windows. If you have separate windows that you'd like to combine, you can merge them into one window with multiple tabs:
- Click on Window at the top of your computer screen.
- Click "Merge All Windows" in the menu that drops down.'

column1: 'Were settings of merge all window changed?'
column4:
'8 - Bring all of the application's windows to the front of the screen.
Bring all of the application's windows to the front of the screen. If you have multiple applications open and you'd like to see all of your work stations for the current application, you can bring them to the front of your screen:
- Click on "Window" at the top of your screen. Do this with the application in question open.
- Click "Bring all to Front". Each window will appear in front of any other apps you have open.'
'0 - Installing macOS Sierra'

'1 - Go to http:__beta.apple.com_sp_betaprogram_.\nGo to http://beta.apple.com/sp/betaprogram/. As of August, 2016, macOS Sierra is only available to the public in its beta version. You can download that version from the Apple website.'
'2 - Click "Sign Up".\nClick "Sign Up". You\'ll be brought to a login page.'
'3 - Log in with your Apple ID.\nLog in with your Apple ID. Enter your Apple ID and Password. Then, click "Sign In."'
'4 - Accept the terms of agreement.\nAccept the terms of agreement. Read the licensing agreement that appears on your screen, scroll to the bottom of the page, and click "Accept."'

5 - Copy your redeem code.\nCopy your redeem code. Although the download will begin automatically, you'll also be shown a code that you can use as proof of your entitlement to the beta software. Copy this code so that it's safe, just in case.\n- To copy the code, click and drag your mouse over it so it highlights blue. Then, press command+c.
'6 - Click "Download the macOS Sierra Public Beta.\nClick "Download the macOS Sierra Public Beta." The App Store will launch on your Mac.'

'7 - Open the App Store.\nOpen the App Store. On your Mac, click on the magnifying glass in the top-right corner of your screen to open Spotlight\'s search function. Type "App Store" into the search bar, and click on the "App Store" result.'
'8 - Click on the "Featured" tab at the top of the window.\nClick on the "Featured" tab at the top of the window.'
'9 - Click "Redeem" in the sidebar on the right.\nClick "Redeem" in the sidebar on the right.'

'10 - Enter your Redeem code.\nEnter your Redeem code. Hit Enter when you are done, and the download will begin automatically.\n- Given that macOS Sierra is a large program, it may take a number of hours to download. You can check the progress of the download by opening the application "Launchpad" in your Finder.'

'11 - Open Launchpad.\nOpen Launchpad. When the download is complete, use Spotlight to search for and open the application called "Launchpad". In your Launchpad, you\'ll now see an icon labelled macOS Sierra.'
'12 - Click "Install" to launch the macOS Sierra Public Beta app.\nClick "Install" to launch the macOS Sierra Public Beta app. Then, click "Continue" on the window that appears.'

13 - Back up your computer.\nBack up your computer. If you haven't backed up your computer recently, click Continue in the dropdown menu that appears. If you have recently backed up your computer or don't care to, click Cancel.
'14 - Accept the licensing terms.\nAccept the licensing terms. Click "Accept" at the bottom of the window that appears to do so. Click "Agree" again to confirm the download.'
'15 - Click Install.\nClick Install. The installation will default to your Macintosh hard drive.'
'16 - Enter your administrator password and click OK.\nEnter your administrator password and click OK.'
'17 - Restart your computer.\nRestart your computer. The update will occur while the computer is restarting.'

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: '0 - Adding a Hot Corner'

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: 1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: '2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: 3 - Click on Mission Control.\nClick on Mission Control. It's at the top of the preferences window.

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: 4 - Click on Hot Corners.\nClick on Hot Corners. It's in the lower left of the dialog box.

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: 5 - Click on one of the four pop-up menus.\nClick on one of the four pop-up menus. Select the corner you'd like to use as the hot corner for the Notification Center.

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: '6 - Click on Notification Center.\nClick on Notification Center.'

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: '7 - Click on OK.\nClick on OK.'

column1: 'Were settings of one of the four pop - up menu changed?'
column4: '8 - Move your cursor into the hot corner.\nMove your cursor into the hot corner. This quickly opens Notification Center.'
'0 - Adding a Hot Corner'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
3 - Click on Mission Control.\nClick on Mission Control. It's at the top of the preferences window.
4 - Click on Hot Corners.\nClick on Hot Corners. It's in the lower left of the dialog box.
5 - Click on one of the four pop-up menus.\nClick on one of the four pop-up menus. Select the corner you'd like to use as the hot corner for the Notification Center.
'6 - Click on Notification Center.\nClick on Notification Center.'
'7 - Click on OK.\nClick on OK.'
'8 - Move your cursor into the hot corner.\nMove your cursor into the hot corner. This quickly opens Notification Center.'
'0 - Adding a Hot Corner'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
3 - Click on Mission Control.\nClick on Mission Control. It's at the top of the preferences window.
4 - Click on Hot Corners.\nClick on Hot Corners. It's in the lower left of the dialog box.
5 - Click on one of the four pop-up menus.\nClick on one of the four pop-up menus. Select the corner you'd like to use as the hot corner for the Notification Center.
'6 - Click on Notification Center.\nClick on Notification Center.'
'7 - Click on OK.\nClick on OK.'
'8 - Move your cursor into the hot corner.\nMove your cursor into the hot corner. This quickly opens Notification Center.'

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: 1 - Click the Apple icon.\nClick the Apple icon. It's the Apple logo at the top left corner of the menu bar.\n- ;

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: '2 - Click System Preferences.\nClick System Preferences.'

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: '3 - Click the "Notifications" icon.\nClick the "Notifications" icon. It looks like a square with a red dot in the corner.\n- If you don\'t see the Notifications icon, click on ⋮⋮⋮⋮ at the top left corner of the window, which displays as Show All in earlier versions of Mac OS X.'

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: '4 - Click Do Not Disturb on the left side of the window.\nClick Do Not Disturb on the left side of the window.'

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: '5 - Click the "When the display is sleeping" check box.\nClick the "When the display is sleeping" check box. It\'s on the right side of the window next to the "Turn on Do Not Disturb" section.'

column1: 'Were settings of when the display be sleep " check box changed?'
column4: '6 - Click the red "x" button.\nClick the red "x" button. Do Not Disturb will turn on whenever your Mac is sleeping!'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '0 - Using WinRAR for Windows'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: 1 - Install WinRAR on your PC.\nInstall WinRAR on your PC. If you don't already have this free archive tool, see Use WinRAR to learn how to get it.\n- ;

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '2 - Press ⊞ Win+E.\nPress ⊞ Win+E. This opens the File Explorer.'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '3 - Browse to the folder with the files you want to zip.\nBrowse to the folder with the files you want to zip.'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '4 - Select the file(s) and_or folder(s) you want to zip.\nSelect the file(s) and/or folder(s) you want to zip. To select more than one file and/or folder at a time, hold Ctrl as you click each file or folder name.'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '5 - Right-click the highlighted file(s).\nRight-click the highlighted file(s). A context menu will expand.'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '6 - Click Add to archive….\nClick Add to archive…. This opens a WinRAR window called “Archive name and parameters.”'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '7 - Name the file.\nName the file. You can type a different file name by erasing the default under "Archive name."\n- Leave ".zip” at the end of the file name to show that it\'s a zip file. For example, archive.zip.'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '8 - Select ZIP under “Archive format.\nSelect ZIP under “Archive format.”'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: 9 - Click Set password….\nClick Set password…. It's at the bottom-right corner of the window. A password entry window will appear.

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: '10 - Enter and confirm a password.\nEnter and confirm a password. You must type the password exactly the same into both blanks.'

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: 11 - Click OK.\nClick OK. It's at the bottom-left corner of the password window.

column1: 'Were settings of click each file or folder name changed?'
column4: 12 - Click OK.\nClick OK. It's at the bottom-center part of the archive window. This creates the zip file and protects it with the password you entered.
