'0 - Using WinRAR for Windows'
1 - Install WinRAR on your PC.\nInstall WinRAR on your PC. If you don't already have this free archive tool, see Use WinRAR to learn how to get it.\n- ;
'2 - Press ⊞ Win+E.\nPress ⊞ Win+E. This opens the File Explorer.'
'3 - Browse to the folder with the files you want to zip.\nBrowse to the folder with the files you want to zip.'

'4 - Select the file(s) and_or folder(s) you want to zip.\nSelect the file(s) and/or folder(s) you want to zip. To select more than one file and/or folder at a time, hold Ctrl as you click each file or folder name.'
'5 - Right-click the highlighted file(s).\nRight-click the highlighted file(s). A context menu will expand.'
'6 - Click Add to archive….\nClick Add to archive…. This opens a WinRAR window called “Archive name and parameters.”'

'7 - Name the file.\nName the file. You can type a different file name by erasing the default under "Archive name."\n- Leave ".zip” at the end of the file name to show that it\'s a zip file. For example, archive.zip.'
'8 - Select ZIP under “Archive format.\nSelect ZIP under “Archive format.”'
9 - Click Set password….\nClick Set password…. It's at the bottom-right corner of the window. A password entry window will appear.
'10 - Enter and confirm a password.\nEnter and confirm a password. You must type the password exactly the same into both blanks.'
11 - Click OK.\nClick OK. It's at the bottom-left corner of the password window.
12 - Click OK.\nClick OK. It's at the bottom-center part of the archive window. This creates the zip file and protects it with the password you entered.
'0 - Confirming your Settings in Terminal'
'1 - Open Terminal.\nOpen Terminal. You can type "Terminal" into Spotlight search to access the program.\n- ;'

'2 - Verify your current settings.
Verify your current settings. The default length of time is 3 seconds.
- Copy and paste the following into the Terminal window: 
- 
- sudo /usr/libexec/PlistBuddy -c "print ':JustASlide:mainDuration'" /System/Library/PrivateFrameworks/Slideshows.framework/Versions/A/Resources/Content/EffectDescriptions.plist
- 
- 
- Press ↵ Enter.
- If prompted for your password, type it in and press ↵ Enter. The keystrokes will not appear as you type it in.
- Unless you have changed this setting before, a number 3 will appear, confirming that the default setting is in place.'
'3 - Click the Apple logo at the top left of your screen.\nClick the Apple logo at the top left of your screen.'
'4 - Click Restart.\nClick Restart.'
'5 - Press and hold ⌘ Command+R immediately after restarting.\nPress and hold ⌘ Command+R immediately after restarting. Doing so will cause your Mac to boot in recovery.'
'1 - Click the Apple logo at the top left of your screen.\nClick the Apple logo at the top left of your screen.'
'2 - Click Restart.\nClick Restart.'
'3 - Press and hold ⌘ Command + R immediately after restarting.\nPress and hold ⌘ Command + R immediately after restarting. Doing so will cause your Mac to boot in recovery.'
'4 - Click Utilities.\nClick Utilities. Once on the recovery screen, you can open Terminal and disable SIP.'
'5 - Click Terminal.\nClick Terminal.'
'6 - Type in csrutil enable.\nType in csrutil enable.'
'7 - Press ↵ Enter.\nPress ↵ Enter.'
8 - Click on the Apple logo.\nClick on the Apple logo. It's at the top left of the menu bar.
'9 - Click Restart.\nClick Restart. SIP will be re-enabled, and your screen saver adjustments will be made!'
'0 - Turning on Dictation'
'1 - .\nDownload macOS. Siri is only available on computers running macOS. If your Mac is running on an earlier operating system, you need to update it to use Siri.\n- ;'
'2 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. The Apple icon is in the upper-left corner of your screen, and will open a drop-down menu.'
'3 - Click "System Preferences.\nClick "System Preferences..." This will open all of the front-end options that you can edit on your Mac.'
'4 - Click the "Keyboard" icon.\nClick the "Keyboard" icon. This is where you\'ll program your Mac to use your voice to perform the Hey Siri command.'
'5 - Click the "Dictation" button.\nClick the "Dictation" button. Dictation converts spoken words into text and can be used to activate a range of commands other than Hey Siri.'
'6 - Click the "On" radio button next to "Dictation.\nClick the "On" radio button next to "Dictation." Also click on the checkbox next to "Use Enhanced Dictation."'

'7 - Select your microphone.\nSelect your microphone. If you have multiple audio input sources for your Mac (such as an external microphone or headphones in addition to your regular built-in microphone), click on the menu underneath the microphone option and click "Internal Microphone."'
'0 - Turning on Hey Siri Using Dictation'
'1 - Click the "View" button.\nClick the "View" button. This button is in the bar at the top of your Mac\'s screen, and will reveal a drop-down menu.'
'2 - Click "Accessibility.\nClick "Accessibility." An interface from your Mac\'s System Preferences will open.'
'3 - Scroll to "Dictation" and click on it.\nScroll to "Dictation" and click on it. The Dictation icon is located in the sidebar on the left of the screen. A new control panel will appear.'

'4 - Check the box next to “Enable the dictation keyword phrase.\nCheck the box next to “Enable the dictation keyword phrase.” You\'ll see a text box open next to the checkbox with the word "Computer" written in it.'
'5 - Replace "Computer" with "Hey" in the text field.\nReplace "Computer" with "Hey" in the text field. This tells your Mac to engage dictation when you say the word "Hey."'

'6 - Click "Dictation Commands.\nClick "Dictation Commands..." This button is located near the top of your current window, and will allow you to define the functions you\'d like your Mac to perform when you use particular phrases after saying the word "Hey."'
'7 - Click "Enable advanced commands.\nClick "Enable advanced commands." This will allow you to customize your dictation commands.'
8 - Click the + button.\nClick the + button. In the window that appears, you'll enter your customized command.

'9 - Enter the custom voice command for "Hey Siri.
Enter the custom voice command for "Hey Siri." On the current menu, you'll see a couple of menus that you can click on to create your custom command. Click on the text windows next to each option and modify them to list the following:
- 
- When I say: Siri
- While using: Any application
- Perform: select "Press Keyboard Shortcut." When the text “Press keys now” shows in gray, press the keyboard shortcut that you use to open Siri. By default, this shortcut is set to ⌘+space.'
'10 - Hit done.\nHit done. Now, anytime you say "Hey Siri," Siri will open on your Mac without you having to lift a finger!'

column1: 'Were settings of do you photo library changed?'
column4:
'1 - Go to https:__overmacs.com_ in a web browser and download the trial.
Go to https://overmacs.com/ in a web browser and download the trial. You can also search the App Store for "PhotoSweeper."
- The full application is $9.99 and will delete similar, but not duplicate, images.
- When you download the trial, you'll download a DMG file that you need to open and move to the Applications folder so you can use the application.'

column1: 'Were settings of do you photo library changed?'
column4: 2 - Open PhotoSweeper.\nOpen PhotoSweeper. This app icon looks like a broom brushing multiple photos. You'll find this in your Applications folder.

column1: 'Were settings of do you photo library changed?'
column4: '3 - Add your Photo library.\nAdd your Photo library. Drag and drop your photo library from Finder into the open PhotoSweeper application window.'

column1: 'Were settings of do you photo library changed?'
column4: '4 - Click Compare and select "Similar Photos.\nClick Compare and select "Similar Photos." You\'ll see the "Compare" button below the imported images. After you select a compare mode, you\'ll see a list of all your duplicate photos.'

column1: 'Were settings of do you photo library changed?'
column4: 5 - Click Auto Mark.\nClick Auto Mark. You'll see this on the toolbar, at the bottom of the application window. This will automatically select all but one duplicate image.

column1: 'Were settings of do you photo library changed?'
column4:
6 - Click Trash Marked.
Click Trash Marked. You'll see this on the toolbar, at the bottom of the application window. All your marked photos will be moved to the trash album.[3]

2 - Open PhotoSweeper.\nOpen PhotoSweeper. This app icon looks like a broom brushing multiple photos. You'll find this in your Applications folder.

'4 - Click Compare and select "Similar Photos.\nClick Compare and select "Similar Photos." You\'ll see the "Compare" button below the imported images. After you select a compare mode, you\'ll see a list of all your duplicate photos.'

2 - Open PhotoSweeper.\nOpen PhotoSweeper. This app icon looks like a broom brushing multiple photos. You'll find this in your Applications folder.

'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'

3 - Click on Spotlight.\nClick on Spotlight. It's in the upper-right of the preferences window.\n- If you don't see all of the System Preferences icons, click on ⋮⋮⋮⋮ in the top bar of the dialog box.
'4 - Click on Search Results.\nClick on Search Results.'
'5 - Check the box next to "Movies."\nCheck the box next to "Movies." It\'s listed alphabetically in the "Search Results" pane. Make sure it\'s blue and displaying a checkmark.'
6 - Click on the Spotlight icon.\nClick on the Spotlight icon. It's the black magnifying glass on the menu bar in the upper-right corner of your screen.
'7 - Type the title of a movie into the search bar.\nType the title of a movie into the search bar. Results will appear in the left pane as you type.'

'8 - Click on the movie title.\nClick on the movie title. It should appear under the "Movies" subheading in the left pane of the dialog box.\n- If your Mac is set to U.K. English, the heading will be "Films."'

'9 - Scroll down to review information about the movie.
Scroll down to review information about the movie. Spotlight will display information about the movie, such as showtimes, rating and cast, in the right pane of the dialog box.
- To purchase tickets online, click on a displayed showtime. This will launch Fandango in your default web browser.
- To purchase or reserve a digital copy of the movie from iTunes, click on the Pre-Order/Buy from iTunes button at the top of the right pane.'
'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
3 - Click on Trackpad.\nClick on Trackpad. It's in the center of the preferences window.
4 - Click on Point & Click.\nClick on Point & Click. It's near the top of the dialog box.
'5 - Click on the checkbox next to "Look up & data detectors."\nClick on the checkbox next to "Look up & data detectors." Make sure the box is blue and contains a checkmark.'

'6 - Click on the drop-down below the checkbox.\nClick on the drop-down below the checkbox. If your Mac is equipped with a Force Trackpad, you will have the option to select Force click. Otherwise, the default gesture is "Tap with three fingers."'
'7 - Highlight any word you wish to look up.\nHighlight any word you wish to look up.'

'8 - Execute the Look Up gesture.\nExecute the Look Up gesture. Either tap three fingers or Force Click on your trackpad. This will quickly give you dictionary entries for the word you want to look up.'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '0 - Editing Using TextEdit'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '1 - Open the Terminal app.\nOpen the Terminal app. You can use the Spotlight search functionality to do this.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '2 - Copy the _etc_hosts file to a local file to be able to edit it.\nCopy the /etc/hosts file to a local file to be able to edit it.\n- Type the command: cp /etc/hosts hosts .'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '3 - Edit the copy of the hosts file using TextEdit.\nEdit the copy of the hosts file using TextEdit.\n- Type the command: open /Applications/TextEdit.app hosts'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '4 - Add your new hosts file entry as a single line at the bottom of the file.\nAdd your new hosts file entry as a single line at the bottom of the file. The format of the line is "1.2.3.4 www.mynewdomain.com", where 1.2.3.4 is the IP address and www.mynewdomain.com is the domain you want to point at the IP address.'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '5 - Copy the file hosts over top of the system _etc_hosts file.\nCopy the file hosts over top of the system /etc/hosts file. Do this by typing: sudo cp hosts\xa0/etc/hosts.\n- You will be prompted for your password at this point because you are overwriting the system /etc/hosts file. Note that on the command line, when you type a character into the password field, nothing at all will appear.'

column1: 'Were settings of cp / etc / host host changed?'
column4: '6 - Test your new local domain name by typing the domain name into your web browser.\nTest your new local domain name by typing the domain name into your web browser.\n- Note: your new domain name will not work until you have a web server responding at the IP address you specify!'

'0 - Editing Using TextEdit'
'1 - Open the Terminal app.\nOpen the Terminal app. You can use the Spotlight search functionality to do this.\n- ;'
'2 - Copy the _etc_hosts file to a local file to be able to edit it.\nCopy the /etc/hosts file to a local file to be able to edit it.\n- Type the command: cp /etc/hosts hosts .'
'3 - Edit the copy of the hosts file using TextEdit.\nEdit the copy of the hosts file using TextEdit.\n- Type the command: open /Applications/TextEdit.app hosts'

'4 - Add your new hosts file entry as a single line at the bottom of the file.\nAdd your new hosts file entry as a single line at the bottom of the file. The format of the line is "1.2.3.4 www.mynewdomain.com", where 1.2.3.4 is the IP address and www.mynewdomain.com is the domain you want to point at the IP address.'

'5 - Copy the file hosts over top of the system _etc_hosts file.\nCopy the file hosts over top of the system /etc/hosts file. Do this by typing: sudo cp hosts\xa0/etc/hosts.\n- You will be prompted for your password at this point because you are overwriting the system /etc/hosts file. Note that on the command line, when you type a character into the password field, nothing at all will appear.'

'6 - Test your new local domain name by typing the domain name into your web browser.\nTest your new local domain name by typing the domain name into your web browser.\n- Note: your new domain name will not work until you have a web server responding at the IP address you specify!'

'0 - Using the Touch Bar with Finder'
'1 - Tap the < and > buttons to move back and forth.\nTap the < and > buttons to move back and forth. This will take you to the previous location or the location you just came from.'

'2 - Tap the Sort button to change the sorting.\nTap the Sort button to change the sorting. This will display a new set of options in the Touch Bar. You can tap how you want icons displayed, as well as the sorting order.'
'3 - Tap the Eye button to open Quick Look.\nTap the Eye button to open Quick Look. This will display the items in your Quick Look folder.'

4 - Tap  (share button) to share your selected files.
Tap  (share button) to share your selected files. This button looks like a square with an arrow coming out of the top. You'll see all of the different sharing options appear, including Mail, Messages, AirDrop, Notes, and any other app that supports file sharing. Swipe left and right to see more options.
- Tapping a sharing option will open that app with the selected files added for sharing.
- The Share button is not available unless files are selected.
'5 - Tap the Tag button to add tags to files and folders.\nTap the Tag button to add tags to files and folders. This allows you to color code your files and folders for easy identification.'
'6 - Tap the X to close.\nTap the X to close. This will close any open submenu in the Touch Bar and return to the Finder navigation menu.'

'0 - Steps'

'1 - Go to https:__www.facebook.com in a web browser.\nGo to https://www.facebook.com in a web browser. If you haven’t already signed in, enter your account information into the blanks at the top-right corner of the page, then click Log In.\n- ;'
'2 - Click the box that says “What’s on your mind?\nClick the box that says “What’s on your mind?” It’s at the top of the page’s center column.'
'3 - Type the text you want to include in your status update.\nType the text you want to include in your status update. Don’t post it yet—you still have to add emoji!'
'4 - Click the smiley face icon.\nClick the smiley face icon. It’s at the bottom-right corner of the box you’re typing in.'

'5 - Click an emoji to include it in your status.\nClick an emoji to include it in your status. To view all of the emoji options, use the gray category buttons (a rabbit, apple, etc) at the bottom of the emoji list.\n- You can add as many emoji as you wish.'
'6 - Click the text box to close the emoji list.\nClick the text box to close the emoji list.'

'7 - Add a Feeling or Activity to your post.
Add a Feeling or Activity to your post. This is optional, but you can click the Feeling/Activity button to include another emoji-like option that displays your current mood or what you’re doing.
- Scroll through the list and click an option that interests you.
- Select one of Facebook’s ideas for a feeling, mood, or activity. Alternatively, you can start typing your own custom answer into the text box above the list.
- When you’re done, the Feeling/Activity list will close and you’ll be back to your new post.'
'8 - Click Post.\nClick Post. Your new status message, including your emoji, will now appear in your timeline.'

'0 - Disabling IPv6'
1 - Open System Preferences.\nOpen System Preferences. You'll find this inside the Apple menu at the top left of your screen.
'2 - Click Network.\nClick Network. This is usually in the third row from the top with "iCloud."'
3 - Click to select your network.\nClick to select your network. You'll see a list of networks in the menu on the left. When you single-click your network, it will highlight in blue.
4 - Click Advanced.\nClick Advanced. You'll find this in the lower right corner of the pop-up window.
5 - Click the TCP_IP tab (if not already active).\nClick the TCP/IP tab (if not already active). You'll see this in the row of tabs with DNS, and Hardware.
'6 - Click {{MacButton|Automatically" next to "Configure IPv6.\nClick {{MacButton|Automatically" next to "Configure IPv6." A menu will drop-down.'
'7 - Select Manually.\nSelect Manually. This is usually the second listing in the drop-down menu.'
'8 - Click OK and Apply to close all windows.\nClick OK and Apply to close all windows.'
'0 - Rotating an Image Using the Trackpad'
'1 - Find the image you want to open.\nFind the image you want to open. You can locate an image using the Finder.\n- ;'

'2 - Press Control + click the mouse button to right click on the image.\nPress Control + click the mouse button to right click on the image.\n- If you have two-finger or corner secondary click enabled, you can use those methods to call up the right click menu as well.'
'3 - Click Open with.\nClick Open with.'

'4 - Click Preview from the drop down list.
Click Preview from the drop down list.
- Note that not every app supports the rotation trackpad gesture. For the best results, open your photo using the Preview or Adobe Photoshop apps.
- You cannot use the rotation gesture in the Photos app.[1]
- X
- Research source'
'5 - Hover your cursor over the image.\nHover your cursor over the image.'
'6 - Place two fingers on the trackpad.\nPlace two fingers on the trackpad.'

'7 - Rotate one finger around the other.\nRotate one finger around the other.\n- For example, if you place your thumb and pointer finger on the trackpad, drag your pointer finger around your thumb in a clockwise or counterclockwise motion.'
8 - Take your fingers off the trackpad's surface.\nTake your fingers off the trackpad's surface. Your image will be rotated!
'0 - Enabling the Rotate Gesture'

1 - Click on the Apple Icon.\nClick on the Apple Icon. It's the Apple logo at the far left corner of the menu bar at the top of your screen.\n- The rotate gesture is enabled by default, but if you need to re-enable it you can do so from the Trackpad menu.
'2 - Click System Preferences.\nClick System Preferences.'

'3 - Click the "Trackpad" icon.\nClick the "Trackpad" icon.\n- If you can\'t see the main menu, click the three rows of dots at the top left corner of the window, which displays as Show All in earlier versions of Mac OS X.'
'4 - Click Scroll & Zoom.\nClick Scroll & Zoom.'
'5 - Check the box next to "Rotate.\nCheck the box next to "Rotate." Doing so will enable the rotate gesture.'
'0 - Backing Up to iCloud'
'1 - Open the Photos app on your Mac.\nOpen the Photos app on your Mac. The Photos app looks like a colored pinwheel in a white circle icon. You can find it in your Applications folder.\n- ;'
'2 - Click the Photos tab on the menu bar.\nClick the Photos tab on the menu bar. You can find it next to the Apple icon in the upper-left corner of your screen. It will open a drop-down menu.'
'3 - Click Preferences on the menu.\nClick Preferences on the menu. This will open your Photos settings in a new window.'
'4 - Click the iCloud tab at the top.\nClick the iCloud tab at the top. This button looks like a  icon at the top of the Preferences window.'

5 - Click and check the iCloud Photo Library option.\nClick and check the iCloud Photo Library option. It's at the top of the iCloud tab here.\n- When this option is checked, all your pictures are automatically uploaded and stored on your iCloud account. You can access all your pictures on all your devices.

6 - Select the Download Originals to this Mac option.\nSelect the Download Originals to this Mac option. You can find it under the iCloud Photo Library heading. This will store full-resolution versions of all your pictures on your Mac.\n- If you select Optimize Mac Storage, you'll download and store low-resolution versions of your pictures on your Mac. You can download the full-resolution version of a picture if you have enough storage space.
'0 - Backing Up to iCloud'
'1 - Open the Photos app on your Mac.\nOpen the Photos app on your Mac. The Photos app looks like a colored pinwheel in a white circle icon. You can find it in your Applications folder.\n- ;'
'2 - Click the Photos tab on the menu bar.\nClick the Photos tab on the menu bar. You can find it next to the Apple icon in the upper-left corner of your screen. It will open a drop-down menu.'
'3 - Click Preferences on the menu.\nClick Preferences on the menu. This will open your Photos settings in a new window.'
'4 - Click the iCloud tab at the top.\nClick the iCloud tab at the top. This button looks like a  icon at the top of the Preferences window.'

5 - Click and check the iCloud Photo Library option.\nClick and check the iCloud Photo Library option. It's at the top of the iCloud tab here.\n- When this option is checked, all your pictures are automatically uploaded and stored on your iCloud account. You can access all your pictures on all your devices.

6 - Select the Download Originals to this Mac option.\nSelect the Download Originals to this Mac option. You can find it under the iCloud Photo Library heading. This will store full-resolution versions of all your pictures on your Mac.\n- If you select Optimize Mac Storage, you'll download and store low-resolution versions of your pictures on your Mac. You can download the full-resolution version of a picture if you have enough storage space.
'0 - Backing Up to an External Drive'
'1 - Open the Photos app on your Mac.\nOpen the Photos app on your Mac. The Photos app looks like a colored pinwheel in a white circle icon. You can find it in your Applications folder.'
'2 - Click the Photos tab on the menu bar.\nClick the Photos tab on the menu bar. You can find it next to the Apple icon in the upper-left corner of your screen. It will open a drop-down menu.'
'3 - Click Preferences on the menu.\nClick Preferences on the menu. This will open your Photos settings in a new window.'

'4 - Click the Show in Finder button next to "Library Location.\nClick the Show in Finder button next to "Library Location." You can find this option at the top of the General tab. It will open a new Finder window, and show your Photos Library file here.'
'5 - Right-click the "Photos Library" file in Finder.\nRight-click the "Photos Library" file in Finder. This will open your right-click options on a drop-down menu.'

'6 - Select Copy on the right-click menu.\nSelect Copy on the right-click menu. This will copy your Photos Library file to your clipboard. You can now paste it to your external drive to keep a manual backup of your pictures.\n- Alternatively, you can select the file, and press ⌘ Command+C on your keyboard to copy it.'

'7 - Connect your external drive and open it on your computer.\nConnect your external drive and open it on your computer. You can find your external drive mounted on your desktop. Double-click on it to open its contents in Finder.'

'8 - Press ⌘ Command+V on your keyboard.\nPress ⌘ Command+V on your keyboard. This will paste the copied Photos Library file to your external drive.\n- Anytime you want to use this backup, copy the Photos Library file from your external drive, and paste it to the original location of the file on your Mac.'
'0 - Steps'
'1 - Make a new folder.\nMake a new folder. If you already have one prepared, skip this step.\n- ;'

'2 - Take a screenshot of any part of your desktop using [Command+Shift+4] and then dragging to form an area.\nTake a screenshot of any part of your desktop using [Command+Shift+4] and then dragging to form an area.'
3 - Open this picture up in preview.\nOpen this picture up in preview. Now here's where it gets complicated.
4 - Open up the toolbar in Preview and select the 'Instant Alpha' function.\nOpen up the toolbar in Preview and select the 'Instant Alpha' function.

'5 - Click and drag with Instant Alpha on until the entire picture is red, then release.\nClick and drag with Instant Alpha on until the entire picture is red, then release. It will select the entire picture.'

'6 - Press delete and then once you can no longer see the picture, type [Command+A].\nPress delete and then once you can no longer see the picture, type [Command+A]. This will select the blank space where the picture used to be.'
'7 - Type [Command+C] to copy that area.\nType [Command+C] to copy that area. You can now exit out of Preview.'
'8 - Right click on the folder you just made _ had and select Get Info.\nRight click on the folder you just made / had and select Get Info.'
'9 - In the top left hand corner there will be a Folder Icon.\nIn the top left hand corner there will be a Folder Icon. Click on this. It should be highlighted in blue.'

'10 - Now (with the icon selected) type [Command+V] to paste the blank picture in.\nNow (with the icon selected) type [Command+V] to paste the blank picture in. There will no longer be an icon visible, and the folder will disappear from your desktop.'

'11 - Now all you have to do is rename the folder (highlight the folder and press Enter) to several spaces (press the spacebar a couple times) and there will be no trace of it on your desktop.\nNow all you have to do is rename the folder (highlight the folder and press Enter) to several spaces (press the spacebar a couple times) and there will be no trace of it on your desktop.'

'12 - The only thing you have left to do is to left click and drag your mouse over the vicinity that the folder was in, drag the folder over to a corner of your desktop where you hardly put files, and then deselect it.\nThe only thing you have left to do is to left click and drag your mouse over the vicinity that the folder was in, drag the folder over to a corner of your desktop where you hardly put files, and then deselect it.'

'13 - When you want to open it again, just select the vicinity again and double click the area where the name of the folder would be.\nWhen you want to open it again, just select the vicinity again and double click the area where the name of the folder would be.'
'0 - Adjusting Your Screen Saver and Sleep Times'

'1 - Click the "Show All" button at the top of the window.\nClick the "Show All" button at the top of the window. This will return you to the System Preferences menu so that you can change the time until your computer goes to sleep or enables the screen saver.'
'2 - Click the "Desktop & Screen Saver" option.\nClick the "Desktop & Screen Saver" option.'
'3 - Click the "Screen Saver" tab.\nClick the "Screen Saver" tab.'
'4 - Click the "Start after" menu.\nClick the "Start after" menu.'

'5 - Click the time that your screen saver should start.\nClick the time that your screen saver should start. If you don\'t want a screen saver, select "Never." Your computer will prompt you for a password once the allotted time has passed after the screen saver activates.'
'6 - Click the "Show All" button.\nClick the "Show All" button. You\'ll now be changing the time until your computer puts itself to sleep.'
'7 - Click the "Energy Saver" option.\nClick the "Energy Saver" option.'

'8 - Click and drag the "Computer sleep" slider.\nClick and drag the "Computer sleep" slider. Your computer will put itself to sleep after this amount of inactivity. You\'ll then be prompted for your password however long after that, depending on what you set earlier in the Security & Privacy menu.'

'5 - Click the time that your screen saver should start.\nClick the time that your screen saver should start. If you don\'t want a screen saver, select "Never." Your computer will prompt you for a password once the allotted time has passed after the screen saver activates.'

You\'ll then be prompted for your password however long after that, depending on what you set earlier in the Security & Privacy menu.'
'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
3 - Click on Keyboard.\nClick on Keyboard. It's in the center of the preferences window.
'4 - Click on Input Sources.\nClick on Input Sources.'
5 - Click on +.\nClick on +. It's beneath the left pane of the dialog box.

6 - Click on the language_region you'd like to add.\nClick on the language/region you'd like to add.\n- You can type the region in the search box under the left pane of the dialog box to avoid scrolling through all available regions and languages.
'7 - Click on Add.\nClick on Add. You have now added a new keyboard region to your Mac.'
'0 - Steps'

'1 - Go to https:__accounts.google.com_signin_recovery in your web browser.
Go to https://accounts.google.com/signin/recovery in your web browser. You can use any web browser, including Chrome or Safari, to recover your deleted Google account.
- If you chose to delete your own account more than three weeks ago, you will be unable to restore the account.
- ;'
'2 - Enter the email address for the account.\nEnter the email address for the account.'
'3 - Click Next.\nClick Next.'

'4 - Enter the last password you remember.\nEnter the last password you remember. If you’re locked out of your account due to a password mishap, remembering one of your older passwords may help you get back in.'

'5 - Click Next.\nClick Next. If the password you entered is the current password, your account will be reactivated immediately. If not, you’ll see a message that displays your recovery email address or phone number.'

'6 - Click Send.\nClick Send. Google will now send a confirmation message to that email address (or a text message to your phone number). It contains a 6-digit code you’ll need to enter on the next screen.'
'7 - Type the 6-digit code into the blank.\nType the 6-digit code into the blank.'
'8 - Click Next.\nClick Next.'

'9 - Reset your Google account password.\nReset your Google account password. Now that you’re back into your account, you’ll have to specify a new password. Type it into the first box, then type it again in the second box to confirm. Once your password is reset, you can sign back into your account on any device.'

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: 1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: '2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: 3 - Click on Security & Privacy.\nClick on Security & Privacy. It's at the top of the preferences window.\n- If you don't see all of the System Preferences icons, click on ⋮⋮⋮⋮ in the top bar of the dialog box.

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: 4 - Click on FileVault.\nClick on FileVault. It's near the top of the dialog box.

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: 5 - Click on the Padlock icon.\nClick on the Padlock icon. It's in the lower-left of the dialog box.

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: 6 - Enter admin credentials.\nEnter admin credentials. Only an administrator can make changes to your Mac's encryption settings.

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: '7 - Click on Turn Off FileVault.\nClick on Turn Off FileVault.'

column1: 'Were settings of turn off filevault changed?'
column4: '8 - Click on Restart & Turn Off Encryption.\nClick on Restart & Turn Off Encryption. Once your computer restarts, automatic encryption will be off on your Mac.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '1 - Assume for the purposes of this tutorial that you\'re trying to find a new icon for the "iMovie" icon.\nAssume for the purposes of this tutorial that you\'re trying to find a new icon for the "iMovie" icon.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '2 - Go to the search bar.\nGo to the search bar. Type in "iMovie Icons" (or whatever the name of the icon you wish to change is, such as "iPhoto Icons", or "Photo Booth icons," and so on.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '3 - Click Enter.\nClick Enter. Browse through all of the icon choices.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '4 - Drag the icon onto your desktop.\nDrag the icon onto your desktop.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '5 - Click on the desktop photo of the icon.\nClick on the desktop photo of the icon. Go to the "Instant Alfa" Tool. This tool allows your icon to have a solid background, so that it can float.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '6 - Click on the solid background of the chosen icon.\nClick on the solid background of the chosen icon. Once you have a red surface on top of the blank solid background, click Enter, and then "Convert".'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '7 - Click on Command, A.\nClick on Command, A. This will select all of the icon.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '8 - Click on Command, C.\nClick on Command, C. This will copy the image.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '9 - Go to your spotlight facility.\nGo to your spotlight facility. Search and type in the icon by typing in "iMovie". Do not click on it.\n- While your mouse is hovering over the highlighted blue app, click on Command, I, which will send it to the information about the icon.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: 10 - Click on the icon's original picture.\nClick on the icon's original picture. Press  Command, V, which will paste the new image on.

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '11 - Quit out of the app.\nQuit out of the app.'

column1: 'Were settings of solid background of the choose icon changed?'
column4: '12 - Click on it again to see the new image appear.\nClick on it again to see the new image appear.\n- It might not appear on the first time, so just keep quitting and re-opening the icon.'

1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
'3 - Click on Printers & Scanners.\nClick on Printers & Scanners.'
'4 - Click on the drop-down menu next to "Default printer."\nClick on the drop-down menu next to "Default printer." It\'s at the bottom of the dialog box and probably reads "Last used."'

'5 - Click on your preferred printer.
Click on your preferred printer. The printer you selected is now the default printer for your Mac.
- Select "Last used" if you want to continue using the same printer you last used.
- Click on +, beneath the left pane, if you'd like to add a new printer.'
'0 - Chrome'
'1 - Right-click on the bookmark you want to change the name of.\nRight-click on the bookmark you want to change the name of.\n- ;'
'2 - Choose Edit from the drop down menu.\nChoose Edit from the drop down menu. A small window should pop up.'
'3 - Type in the new name you want the bookmark to be named after.\nType in the new name you want the bookmark to be named after.'
4 - Type in the URL you want the bookmark to lead to, if you'd like.\nType in the URL you want the bookmark to lead to, if you'd like.
5 - Click Save when you're done.\nClick Save when you're done.\n- The bookmark's name should have a different name after clicking Save.
'0 - Installing Windows'

1 - Check the system requirements.\nCheck the system requirements. Before your buy any Windows software, you need to make sure it's compatible with your system; otherwise it won't work. If you're not sure which OS X version, processor, memory (RAM) and hard drive space your computer has, then use about system information to find out.

'2 - Choose a compatible Windows version.
Choose a compatible Windows version. Check which versions of Windows will work with your Mac.[1]
- X
- Research source'

3 - Purchase Windows.\nPurchase Windows. If you have a Windows copy on a DVD, you need to create a disk image. If you have a copy on a flash drive, you just need to to download the ISO disk image from Microsoft. Otherwise, you need to buy full Windows version that come as a disk image file (ISO).\n- Purchasing a brand new Windows copy is a bit expensive. There are discounts available for students. Make sure you save product key somewhere safe, because you'll need it later.
'4 - Download Windows.\nDownload Windows. This is an easy step; just follow the Windows setup instructions and save the file to your desktop.'

5 - Start the installation.\nStart the installation. When you first open Parallels, it's going to give you two options. You can choose the first one: “Install Windows or another OS from a DVD or image file”.
'6 - Click Continue.\nClick Continue.'
'7 - Enter the product key you were given when you purchased Windows.\nEnter the product key you were given when you purchased Windows.'

'8 - Pick your integration preference.\nPick your integration preference. If you want\xa0Windows and all its programs and applications to appear in one window, choose the second option. However, both options work fine; the only difference is how the files will display on your computer.'
'9 - Click Continue and choose a name and location.\nClick Continue and choose a name and location.'
'10 - Wait and let Parallels do its magic.\nWait and let Parallels do its magic. The installation period shouldn’t take longer than 20 minutes.'

'11 - Start up and use Parallels.
Start up and use Parallels.
- You can make the Windows a full screen so it looks like it would if you were using a regular Windows PC by choosing full screen mode.
- To switch back and forth between Mac and Windows, make sure to share Windows applications with Mac.[2]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- Since the virtual machine is set up now, you can run any Windows application. Next part we are going to install Microsoft Visual Studio.'

'1 - Click the Apple logo in the top-left corner of your screen.\nClick the Apple logo in the top-left corner of your screen. A general menu will appear.'
'2 - Click "System Preferences".\nClick "System Preferences". This is where you can edit your computer\'s front-end settings.'

'3 - Click "Siri".\nClick "Siri". This should be in the bottom row of your System Preferences.\n- If you don\'t see a "Siri" option, click on the box of dots located at the top of the System Preferences window.'

'4 - Turn Siri on_off.\nTurn Siri on/off. On the left half of the window, click the checkbox next to "Enable Siri" to allow Siri to be opened on your computer.\n- When Siri is disabled, this simply means that you will be prompted as to whether or not you would like to allow Siri to access your microphone when you open the app.'
'5 - Change Siri\'s language.\nChange Siri\'s language. Click on the "Language" bar at the top of the screen to change the language that Siri will listen to and respond in when you use the app.'
'6 - Change Siri\'s voice.\nChange Siri\'s voice. Click on the "Siri Voice" bar to change the gender and accent that Siri replicates when responding to your queries.'

'7 - Change your input source.\nChange your input source. If you would like to address Siri using an input other than your computer\'s built-in microphone, click the box next to "Mic input" and select your preferred option from the list.\n- Siri will default to using your internal microphone to hear your voice. You will need to have another microphone plugged into your computer to change this option.'

'8 - Set a keyboard shortcut to open Siri.\nSet a keyboard shortcut to open Siri. By default, Siri can be opened by holding command+spacebar. If you would like to change this option, click the "Keyboard Shortcut" bar and choose one of the options listed, or click "Customize..." to set your own shortcut.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu. This is in the upper-left corner of the screen.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '2 - Click the "System Preferences" option.\nClick the "System Preferences" option. If a menu other than the main System Preferences menu opens, click the "Show All" button at the top of the window. The button is a grid of 12 dots.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '3 - Click "Language & Region."\nClick "Language & Region."'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '4 - Click "+" underneath the "Preferred languages" list.\nClick "+" underneath the "Preferred languages" list.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '5 - Click the language that you want to add.\nClick the language that you want to add.\n- Languages below the line in the list are not fully supported by macOS, and may not show in all menus and apps.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '6 - Click the "Add" button.\nClick the "Add" button.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '7 - Click the language you want to use as your primary.\nClick the language you want to use as your primary. You can choose to continue using your original language or select the new language.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '8 - Click "Add Input Source" if new input sources are available.\nClick "Add Input Source" if new input sources are available. If you added a language that uses a different keyboard layout than your own, you\'ll be asked if you want to add it to your input sources. You can skip this if you don\'t plan on typing in that language.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: '9 - Click and drag a language to change the primary language.\nClick and drag a language to change the primary language. Moving a language to the top of the "Preferred languages" list will make it the default language.'

column1: 'Were settings of language that you want to add . changed?'
column4: 10 - Restart your Mac for your changes to take effect.\nRestart your Mac for your changes to take effect. Your language settings won't change in most menus and apps until your restart your computer.
'0 - Steps'
'1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu. This is in the upper-left corner of the screen.\n- ;'

'2 - Click the "System Preferences" option.\nClick the "System Preferences" option. If a menu other than the main System Preferences menu opens, click the "Show All" button at the top of the window. The button is a grid of 12 dots.'
'3 - Click "Language & Region."\nClick "Language & Region."'
'4 - Click "+" underneath the "Preferred languages" list.\nClick "+" underneath the "Preferred languages" list.'

'5 - Click the language that you want to add.\nClick the language that you want to add.\n- Languages below the line in the list are not fully supported by macOS, and may not show in all menus and apps.'
'6 - Click the "Add" button.\nClick the "Add" button.'
'7 - Click the language you want to use as your primary.\nClick the language you want to use as your primary. You can choose to continue using your original language or select the new language.'

'8 - Click "Add Input Source" if new input sources are available.\nClick "Add Input Source" if new input sources are available. If you added a language that uses a different keyboard layout than your own, you\'ll be asked if you want to add it to your input sources. You can skip this if you don\'t plan on typing in that language.'

'9 - Click and drag a language to change the primary language.\nClick and drag a language to change the primary language. Moving a language to the top of the "Preferred languages" list will make it the default language.'
10 - Restart your Mac for your changes to take effect.\nRestart your Mac for your changes to take effect. Your language settings won't change in most menus and apps until your restart your computer.
'0 - Steps'
'1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu. This is in the upper-left corner of the screen.\n- ;'

'2 - Click the "System Preferences" option.\nClick the "System Preferences" option. If a menu other than the main System Preferences menu opens, click the "Show All" button at the top of the window. The button is a grid of 12 dots.'
'3 - Click "Language & Region."\nClick "Language & Region."'
'4 - Click "+" underneath the "Preferred languages" list.\nClick "+" underneath the "Preferred languages" list.'

'5 - Click the language that you want to add.\nClick the language that you want to add.\n- Languages below the line in the list are not fully supported by macOS, and may not show in all menus and apps.'
'6 - Click the "Add" button.\nClick the "Add" button.'
'7 - Click the language you want to use as your primary.\nClick the language you want to use as your primary. You can choose to continue using your original language or select the new language.'

'8 - Click "Add Input Source" if new input sources are available.\nClick "Add Input Source" if new input sources are available. If you added a language that uses a different keyboard layout than your own, you\'ll be asked if you want to add it to your input sources. You can skip this if you don\'t plan on typing in that language.'

'9 - Click and drag a language to change the primary language.\nClick and drag a language to change the primary language. Moving a language to the top of the "Preferred languages" list will make it the default language.'
10 - Restart your Mac for your changes to take effect.\nRestart your Mac for your changes to take effect. Your language settings won't change in most menus and apps until your restart your computer.

'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple icon.\nClick on the Apple icon. It's the Apple logo at the far-left side of the menu bar at the top of your screen.\n- ;
'2 - Click System Preferences.\nClick System Preferences.'

'3 - Click the "Keyboard" icon.\nClick the "Keyboard" icon.\n- If you can\'t see the main menu, click the three rows of dots at the top left corner of the window, which displays as Show All in earlier versions of Mac OS X.'
'4 - Click Shortcuts.\nClick Shortcuts.'

'5 - Click "Launchpad & Dock" from the menu on the left.\nClick "Launchpad & Dock" from the menu on the left. One dock option, "Turn Dock Hiding On/Off," will appear on the right side of the window.\n- The default keyboard shortcut is ⌥ Option+⌘ Command+D.'
'6 - Click the box next to "Turn Dock Hiding On_Off.\nClick the box next to "Turn Dock Hiding On/Off."'
'7 - Click on the shortcut combination on the right to edit it.\nClick on the shortcut combination on the right to edit it.'

'8 - Type in your custom shortcut.
Type in your custom shortcut. You'll want to start the shortcut with a modifier key such as the ⌘ Command, ⌥ Option, Fn, Control, ⇬ Caps Lock, or ⇧ Shift keys.[1]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- If you're using an "F" function key, you will have to hold down the Fn key to type your command.
- Make sure your new shortcut is unique, meaning that no other shortcuts have been assigned to the key combination you enter.'
'9 - Click the red "X" button.\nClick the red "X" button. Your custom shortcut for dock hiding will be saved, and you can activate the shortcut anytime by pressing your custom key combination.'
'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple icon.\nClick on the Apple icon. It's the Apple logo at the top left corner of the menu bar.\n- ;
'2 - Click System Preferences.\nClick System Preferences.'
'3 - Click the "Trackpad" icon.\nClick the "Trackpad" icon.'

'4 - Click the first check box to enable "Look up & data detectors.\nClick the first check box to enable "Look up & data detectors." An animation will display on the right side of the window, showing you an example of the three-finger tap to show lookup & data detectors.'

'5 - Click the check box next to "Secondary click" to enable it.\nClick the check box next to "Secondary click" to enable it. An animation will display on the right side of the window, showing you an example of the two-finger secondary menu tap.\n- Click the drop-down arrow to select a different option for a secondary click.'

'6 - Click the check box next to "Tap to click" to enable it.\nClick the check box next to "Tap to click" to enable it. An animation will display on the right side of the window, showing you an example of the one-finger tap to click.'
'7 - Click the red "X" button.\nClick the red "X" button. Your tap to click setting will be saved!'
'0 - External iSight Method'
'1 - Plug in your iSight to your Mac.\nPlug in your iSight to your Mac. It should recognize it.\n- ;'
'2 - Go to iMovie'
'Go to iMovie'
'3 - On iMovie, go to the option where it has a video camera'
'On iMovie, go to the option where it has a video camera'
'4 - Click "Record with iSight"'
'Click "Record with iSight"'
'5 - Done!\nDone!'
'0 - Moving Your Data'

'1 - Download OneDrive on your Mac.\nDownload OneDrive on your Mac.  OneDrive automatically syncs with Microsoft Windows 10 PCs when connected to the Internet.  It is also available for your iPhone and Android for free.\n- ;'

2 - Sign in with_create a Microsoft account on OneDrive.\nSign in with/create a Microsoft account on OneDrive.  PCs work best when signed into Microsoft accounts, and allow you to install Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, sync your stuff, and use Cortana.  Plus, it's free.

'3 - Check all of the boxes pertaining to syncing files.
Check all of the boxes pertaining to syncing files.  You will need to sync each and every file possible.  OneDrive by default has about 16 GB of free storage, but storage plans extend to about 1 TB of storage.
- You should upgrade your storage if your overall disk space takes up more than 16 GB.
- Office 365 subscribers get a free TB of storage, so have your friends temporarily share their subscription, or share a subscription with your family.'

4 - Go to the Applications folder.
Go to the Applications folder.  This is located at /var/Applications.  Search up every app on your Mac for your Windows 10 PC in the Microsoft Store (don't forget to sign in), and download them.  Apps not available in the Microsoft Store can be downloaded from the software vendor's website.
- Depending on your PC, you may be locked down to Windows Store apps, but you can upgrade from Windows 10 S to Windows 10 Home/Pro to install these apps.
- Be sure to have product keys/app accounts ready so that you can use those apps on Windows.
'5 - Sign in to OneDrive on Windows.\nSign in to OneDrive on Windows.  Click on the OneDrive icon on the system tray, choose sign in, then enter your account details.  Do not sync anything yet.'
'6 - Open OneDrive preferences and check the box under "Files On-Demand" in "Settings".\nOpen OneDrive preferences and check the box under "Files On-Demand" in "Settings".'
'7 - Click "Account", and check all the boxes to show all the files on File Explorer.\nClick "Account", and check all the boxes to show all the files on File Explorer.'

'8 - Under "Protect your Important folders", click on "Update Folders".\nUnder "Protect your Important folders", click on "Update Folders". Choose to protect all of the folders so your Mac Desktop and other components show up on your PC.'

'9 - Download the files you wish to.\nDownload the files you wish to. Opening a file will download a file temporarily.  To download a file permanently, choose "Keep on this device" from the right click menu. Choose "Free up space" to remove a file.'

'0 - Using System Preferences'

'1 - Open your Mac’s System Preferences panel.\nOpen your Mac’s System Preferences panel. Click the Apple icon in the upper-left corner of your screen and select System Preferences on the drop-down menu. It will open a new pop-up window.'

2 - Click the Displays button.\nClick the Displays button. This option looks like a desktop monitor icon towards the upper-left corner of the System Preferences window. It will open a menu where you can change your computer's display resolution, brightness, and color settings.

'3 - Click the Night Shift tab.\nClick the Night Shift tab. Displays menu will open up to the Display tab. Click the Night Shift tab at the top of the window in order to set up your Night Shift settings.'

'4 - Click the drop-down arrows next to Schedule.
Click the drop-down arrows next to Schedule. This option lets you set up a schedule for Night Shift to automatically turn on and off after dark every day. It is set to Off by default. You can select to schedule it from Sunset to Sunrise according to your local time, or you can set up your own Custom schedule.
- If you select Sunset to Sunrise, Night Shift will automatically turn on every day at your local sunset time and turn off at sunrise. Your Mac will use your time zone settings to update sunset and sunrise times every day.
- If you select Custom, you will have the option to type in your own timeframe to turn on and off. You can always go back and change your times.'

5 - Click and check the box next to Manual.\nClick and check the box next to Manual. If you don't want to set up a Night Shift schedule, you can manually turn it on by checking this box.\n- Click again and uncheck the box to turn it off.

6 - Click and drag the slider next to Color Temperature.\nClick and drag the slider next to Color Temperature. You can use this slider to find the most comfortable color temperature for your own eyes and make it your designated Night Shift setting. Your computer's display will shift to this color when you have Night Shift on.

column1: 'Were settings of adobe lightroom download page changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of adobe lightroom download page changed?'
column4:
1 - Open the Adobe Lightroom download page in your internet browser.
Open the Adobe Lightroom download page in your internet browser.
- If you're automatically signed in to Adobe, your download will start immediately. This will download Lightroom with a 7-day free trial license.
- If you're not automatically signed in, you'll be prompted to sign in with your Adobe ID.
- After the 7-day trial, you can compare full-access plans, and purchase a monthly subscription from here.
- ;

column1: 'Were settings of adobe lightroom download page changed?'
column4:
2 - Click the Sign in button.
Click the Sign in button. This will open the sign-in form, and allow you to sign in with your Adobe ID.
- If you don't have an Adobe account, you can click the Sign up button here to create a new account.
- Alternatively, you can sign in with your Facebook or Google account. Just click the button at the bottom of the page.

column1: 'Were settings of adobe lightroom download page changed?'
column4: '3 - Select your skill level with Lightroom.\nSelect your skill level with Lightroom. Click the drop-down, and select Beginner, Intermediate or Advanced to indicate your skill level.\n- Your selection will not affect your download.'

column1: 'Were settings of adobe lightroom download page changed?'
column4: '4 - Click the blue Continue button.\nClick the blue Continue button. This will confirm your selection, and take you to the download page.\n- Your browser will automatically prompt you to confirm and start the download in a pop-up.'

column1: 'Were settings of adobe lightroom download page changed?'
column4: '5 - Click the Open Adobe Application button in the confirmation pop-up.\nClick the Open Adobe Application button in the confirmation pop-up. This will start your download, and prompt the Creative Cloud desktop app to install the Lightroom app.\n- You can find Lightroom in your Applications folder when the download is finished.'

3 - Click on Bluetooth.\nClick on Bluetooth. It's in the center of the preferences window.

'5 - Click on <.\nClick on <. It\'s in the upper-left corner of the dialog box. This returns you the main "System Preferences" screen.'

'10 - Click on Continue.\nClick on Continue.'
'11 - Follow any additional pairing instructions.\nFollow any additional pairing instructions. You have now set up the Bluetooth trackpad for your Mac.'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '1 - Open the Notes app on your Mac.\nOpen the Notes app on your Mac. The Notes icon looks like a white-and-yellow, ruled notepad in your Applications folder.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '2 - Click on a note with an image in it.\nClick on a note with an image in it. The Notes app will show you a list of all your notes on the left-hand side of the app window. Notes with images in them will have an image thumbnail on the list.'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '3 - Hover over the image in the note.\nHover over the image in the note. Use your mouse or touchpad to move your cursor on the image. A downward-facing arrow icon will appear in the upper-right corner of the image.'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '4 - Click the downward-facing arrow icon.\nClick the downward-facing arrow icon. This button appears in the upper-right corner of the image when you hover over it. It will open a drop-down menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '5 - Click Markup.\nClick Markup. This option is listed next to a toolbox icon at the top of the drop-down menu. It will open your image in Markup editor.'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4:
6 - Select the Markup tool you want to use.
Select the Markup tool you want to use. You will have a handful of options on the toolbar at the top of the image.
- Click one of the Sketch or Draw icons if you want to use your mouse to draw a line on the image.  They're in the upper-left corner of the Markup window.
- Click the Shapes icon if you want to add a geometric shape or a straight line. You will be able to select a shape from a drop-down menu.
- Click the T icon if you want to add a text box. You can use your keyboard to type in text in a text box, and place it anywhere on the image.
- Click the Sign icon if you want to add your signature on the image. You will be able to use your trackpad to sign your name, or use your camera to scan your signature.

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: 7 - Click the three horizontal lines icon on the toolbar.\nClick the three horizontal lines icon on the toolbar. It's the Shape Style button. This button will allow you to select a border thickness for the Sketch, Draw, and Shapes tools.

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: 8 - Click the empty square icon next to the Shape Style button.\nClick the empty square icon next to the Shape Style button. It's the Border Color button. This button will let you select a color for your Sketch and Draw lines. It will also change the border colors of Shapes.

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: 9 - Click the filled square icon.\nClick the filled square icon. It's the Fill Color button. It will let you select a color to fill up the inside of Shapes.

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: '10 - Click the "A" letter icon.\nClick the "A" letter icon. It\'s the Text Style button. This button will allow you to customize the text in a text box by changing its font, size, color, style, and alignment.'

column1: 'Were settings of note with a image changed?'
column4: 11 - Tap Done.\nTap Done. It's in the upper-right corner of the image. It will save your edits and quit the Markup editor.

'4 - Click the downward-facing arrow icon.\nClick the downward-facing arrow icon. This button appears in the upper-right corner of the image when you hover over it. It will open a drop-down menu.'
'5 - Click Markup.\nClick Markup. This option is listed next to a toolbox icon at the top of the drop-down menu. It will open your image in Markup editor.'

6 - Select the Markup tool you want to use.
Select the Markup tool you want to use. You will have a handful of options on the toolbar at the top of the image.
- Click one of the Sketch or Draw icons if you want to use your mouse to draw a line on the image.  They're in the upper-left corner of the Markup window.
- Click the Shapes icon if you want to add a geometric shape or a straight line. You will be able to select a shape from a drop-down menu.
- Click the T icon if you want to add a text box. You can use your keyboard to type in text in a text box, and place it anywhere on the image.
- Click the Sign icon if you want to add your signature on the image. You will be able to use your trackpad to sign your name, or use your camera to scan your signature.

7 - Click the three horizontal lines icon on the toolbar.\nClick the three horizontal lines icon on the toolbar. It's the Shape Style button. This button will allow you to select a border thickness for the Sketch, Draw, and Shapes tools.

8 - Click the empty square icon next to the Shape Style button.\nClick the empty square icon next to the Shape Style button. It's the Border Color button. This button will let you select a color for your Sketch and Draw lines. It will also change the border colors of Shapes.
9 - Click the filled square icon.\nClick the filled square icon. It's the Fill Color button. It will let you select a color to fill up the inside of Shapes.

'10 - Click the "A" letter icon.\nClick the "A" letter icon. It\'s the Text Style button. This button will allow you to customize the text in a text box by changing its font, size, color, style, and alignment.'
11 - Tap Done.\nTap Done. It's in the upper-right corner of the image. It will save your edits and quit the Markup editor.
'0 - Steps'
'1 - Open the Notes app on your Mac.\nOpen the Notes app on your Mac. The Notes icon looks like a white-and-yellow, ruled notepad in your Applications folder.\n- ;'

'2 - Click on a note with an image in it.\nClick on a note with an image in it. The Notes app will show you a list of all your notes on the left-hand side of the app window. Notes with images in them will have an image thumbnail on the list.'

'3 - Hover over the image in the note.\nHover over the image in the note. Use your mouse or touchpad to move your cursor on the image. A downward-facing arrow icon will appear in the upper-right corner of the image.'
'4 - Click the downward-facing arrow icon.\nClick the downward-facing arrow icon. This button appears in the upper-right corner of the image when you hover over it. It will open a drop-down menu.'
'5 - Click Markup.\nClick Markup. This option is listed next to a toolbox icon at the top of the drop-down menu. It will open your image in Markup editor.'

6 - Select the Markup tool you want to use.
Select the Markup tool you want to use. You will have a handful of options on the toolbar at the top of the image.
- Click one of the Sketch or Draw icons if you want to use your mouse to draw a line on the image.  They're in the upper-left corner of the Markup window.
- Click the Shapes icon if you want to add a geometric shape or a straight line. You will be able to select a shape from a drop-down menu.
- Click the T icon if you want to add a text box. You can use your keyboard to type in text in a text box, and place it anywhere on the image.
- Click the Sign icon if you want to add your signature on the image. You will be able to use your trackpad to sign your name, or use your camera to scan your signature.

7 - Click the three horizontal lines icon on the toolbar.\nClick the three horizontal lines icon on the toolbar. It's the Shape Style button. This button will allow you to select a border thickness for the Sketch, Draw, and Shapes tools.

8 - Click the empty square icon next to the Shape Style button.\nClick the empty square icon next to the Shape Style button. It's the Border Color button. This button will let you select a color for your Sketch and Draw lines. It will also change the border colors of Shapes.
9 - Click the filled square icon.\nClick the filled square icon. It's the Fill Color button. It will let you select a color to fill up the inside of Shapes.

'10 - Click the "A" letter icon.\nClick the "A" letter icon. It\'s the Text Style button. This button will allow you to customize the text in a text box by changing its font, size, color, style, and alignment.'
11 - Tap Done.\nTap Done. It's in the upper-right corner of the image. It will save your edits and quit the Markup editor.
'0 - Steps'
1 - Click on the Apple menu.\nClick on the Apple menu. It's the black, apple-shaped icon in the upper-left of your screen.\n- ;
'2 - Click on System Preferences.\nClick on System Preferences.'
3 - Click on Notifications.\nClick on Notifications. It's near the top right of the Preferences window.
'4 - Click on Do Not Disturb.\nClick on Do Not Disturb. It appears at the top of the left pane of the dialog box.'

'5 - Click on checkboxes next to select your Do Not Disturb preferences.
Click on checkboxes next to select your Do Not Disturb preferences.
- You can schedule times when Do Not Disturb is automatic, such as during night hours. In addition, you can activate Do Not Disturb when the display is sleeping or mirroring on a TV or projector. This prevents others from publicly seeing notifications on your Mac.
- When Do Not Disturb is activated during a scheduled time, a "Do Not Disturb" slider will appear at the top of the Notification Center. When activated, you can use this slider to toggle Do Not Disturb on and off.
- When Do Not Disturb is activated, you can also choose to allow calls from everyone and allow repeated calls, if you prefer.'
6 - Click on the Notification Center icon.\nClick on the Notification Center icon. This is the icon in the menu bar at the top-right corner of your Mac's screen.
'7 - Scroll up.\nScroll up. Doing so will reveal the Do Not Disturb Slider.'
'8 - Click on the slider.\nClick on the slider. This will turn Do Not Disturb on as specified by the preferences you set in System Preferences.'

'0 - Using Google Drive'
'1 - Navigate to https:__drive.google.com_ on your Mac.\nNavigate to https://drive.google.com/ on your Mac.'
'2 - Sign into your Google account.\nSign into your Google account.\n- If you do not have a Google account, you will need to make one.'
'3 - Click New.\nClick New.'
'4 - Click File Upload.\nClick File Upload.\n- You can also click Folder Upload to upload multiple documents.'
'5 - Select a file on your computer to upload.\nSelect a file on your computer to upload.'
'6 - Click Open.\nClick Open.\n- You can also drag and drop files into the Google Drive window to upload them.'

'7 - Navigate to https:__drive.google.com_ on your other device.\nNavigate to https://drive.google.com/ on your other device.\n- If you are using an iOS or Android device, you can also download the Google Drive app.'

'8 - Sign into your Google account.\nSign into your Google account. You will have access to all of your files uploaded from your Mac.\n- You can click/tap a document to view it or open the menu for a document and click/tap Download to save it to your device.'

'0 - Steps'

1 - Make sure your Messages app is all set up to work on your computer.\nMake sure your Messages app is all set up to work on your computer. If you don't have that working yet, you just need to activate iMessages on your desktop or laptop.\n- ;
'2 - Open Messages.\nOpen Messages.'
'3 - Locate the message you want to react to.\nLocate the message you want to react to.'

'4 - Hit Ctrl and click the message.\nHit Ctrl and click the message. If you\'re using a laptop, you can use two fingers on the touchpad at once to "right-click." If you have a mouse with two buttons, you can also right-click directly on it.'
5 - Select Tapback from the menu.\nSelect Tapback from the menu. You'll see a reaction menu pop up.

'6 - Pick your reaction.\nPick your reaction. You\'ll have a choice between a heart, thumbs up, thumbs down, "Ha Ha," exclamation points, or question mark.\n- As soon as you pick it, it\'ll send that reaction to your recipient. There\'s no need to hit send or click anything else.'
'0 - Troubleshooting with Disk Management on Windows'

1 - Right-click the Windows Start button.\nRight-click the Windows Start button.  It's the button in the lower-left corner of the task bar.  Right-clicking the Start button displays a list of managers you can use to troubleshoot issues on your computer.
'2 - Click Disk Management.\nClick Disk Management.  This opens the Disk Management program on your computer.'

'3 - Right-click the external hard drive (if displayed).\nRight-click the external hard drive (if displayed).  If the external hard drive is displayed in Disk Management, right-click it to display a pop-up window.'
'4 - Click Change Drive Letter and Paths.\nClick Change Drive Letter and Paths.  This displays a box that allows you to change the drive letter for the device.'
'5 - Click Change.\nClick Change.  This allows you to change the drive letter.'

'6 - Select a new drive letter and click Ok.\nSelect a new drive letter and click Ok.  Use the drop-down menu next to "Assign the following drive letter" to select a new drive letter for the external hard drive.  Click Ok when you are finished.  Changing the drive letter may force Windows to recognize the hard drive.'
'7 - Right-click any unallocated space.\nRight-click any unallocated space.  If there is any unallocated space on the hard drive, it needs to be initialized in order to be recognized by Windows.'
'8 - Click Initialize Disk.\nClick Initialize Disk.  This opens a window that allows you to initialize the Disk.'

'9 - Click Ok.
Click Ok.  This initializes the disk so that it is recognized by Windows.
- By default, the disk will be initialized as a "MBR (Master Boot Record)".  If the external hard drive is larger than 2 terabytes, select "GPT (GUIT Partition Table}.[2]
- X
- Research source'

'10 - Format the drive.
Format the drive.  If the external hard drive was formatted on another computer platform, such as Mac or Linux, it may not be recognized by Windows.  If all else fails, you can reformat the drive for Windows.  If you plan on using the external hard drive only on Windows, select NTFS as the file system.  If you plan on using it with other devices, select FAT32 as the file system.  Warning:  Formatting the external hard drive will permanently erase all the data on the external hard drive.  Use this step as a last resort.  If possible, try to backup any files you want to keep to another computer.  Use the following steps to format the hard drive.
- Right-click the external hard drive in Disk Management.
- Click Format.
- Type a name for the drive.
- Select NTFS or FAT32 next to "File System".
- Click Ok.'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4: '0 - Configuring Your Mac'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4: '1 - Choose your language.\nChoose your language. The first thing the setup will ask you to do is to choose your native language. Scroll down the list to highlight the language you wish to use and press the “Return” key on your keyboard to select it and proceed to the next step.'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4: '2 - Choose your keyboard.\nChoose your keyboard. If you’re using a Mac Mini, the setup will require you to choose what kind of keyboard you like to use. Highlight the keyboard of your choice from the list and click the “Continue” button to proceed.'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4:
'3 - Connect your Mac to the Internet.
Connect your Mac to the Internet. Select the Wi-Fi network from the list of available connections detected by the computer. Click on the access point you want to connect to and select “Continue” to proceed.
- If the access point you wish to connect to is password protected, a text field will appear right below the list where you can type the password before hitting “Continue.”
- If you prefer using a wired connection, take the Internet cable coming from your router or modem and plug it into the LAN port at the back of the computer or along the sides if you’re using a laptop.'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4: '4 - Transfer information to this Mac.\nTransfer information to this Mac. You can get your saved files and documents from your old computer (Mac or Windows) and move it to your Mac. To do this, select from which computer you’d like to get your files and click the “Continue” button.\n- Transferring files from your old computer to your Mac will take a lot of time, depending on the amount of files to be moved. If you want to finish the setup first, simply select “Not Now” from the list. You can transfer the files later once your Mac has been configured.'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4: '5 - Enable location services.\nEnable location services. The next step will ask you if you want your Mac to determine your exact location and save it in its settings. This allows the built in apps on the Mac, like maps, iTunes and more, to work more accurately and display information relevant to where you are.\n- To enable this option, put a check mark on the box you’ll see on this page and click “Continue.” Otherwise, you can just leave it blank and move on.'

column1: 'Were settings of choose you language changed?'
column4:
'6 - Sign in with your Apple ID.
Sign in with your Apple ID. On the next page, you’ll need to enter your Apple ID. Enter the account credentials on the allocated text fields and hit “Continue” again to proceed.
- If you don’t have an Apple ID yet, you can get one clicking the “Create a Free Apple ID” on the lower-left corner of the setup window.
- If you wish to sign in later, you can just click the “Skip” button to continue on to the next step without signing in.'
