'0 - On MacOS'

'1 - Check to see if you can install a new hard drive to your Mac.\nCheck to see if you can install a new hard drive to your Mac.  Macs are notoriously difficult to upgrade.  The method for installing a hard drive is different from one Mac model to another.  Some models may not allow you to install a new hard drive.  Many models may require you to take your Mac to an Apple authorized service provider to replace your hard drive.  Click here to see if your Mac allows you to install a new hard drive.'

'2 - Purchase an SSD enclosure.\nPurchase an SSD enclosure.  In order to transfer your MacOS to a new SSD, you will need to an external enclosure.  This allows you to connect the SSD to your Mac using a USB.  Make sure you purchase the right size enclosure for your SSD.'

'3 - Back up your old hard drive.\nBack up your old hard drive.  Before doing any repairs or upgrades, it\'s important to back up all the data on your old hard drive.  This protects your data in case something goes wrong.  If your SSD has smaller storage space than your old drive, it may be necessary to delete some files so that your old hard drive will be able to fit on the new SSD.   Read "How to Back Up A Computer" to learn more about how to back up the files on your computer.'

4 - Remove excess files from your old hard drive (if needed).\nRemove excess files from your old hard drive (if needed).  If your new SSD is smaller than your old hard drive, it may be necessary to delete files you don't need so that all the contents of your old hard drive will fit on your new SSD.  As long as your files are backed up, you should be able to access them later.
'5 - Connect the SSD to your Mac.\nConnect the SSD to your Mac.  Place the SSD inside the enclosure and connect it to your Mac using an available USB port.'
6 - Open the Finder .\nOpen the Finder .  It's the app that has a blue and white icon with a smiley face.

'7 - Type Disk Utility in the search bar and open the Disk Utility.\nType Disk Utility in the search bar and open the Disk Utility.  The search bar is in the upper-right corner of the finder.  Typing "Disk Utility" will display the Disk Utility app.  It has an icon that resembles a hard drive with a stethoscope.  Click this app as soon as it appears.'
'8 - Select the SSD.\nSelect the SSD.  The SSD is listed in the sidebar to the left under "External".  Usually, it will be listed under the name of the manufacturer.'
9 - Click Erase.\nClick Erase.  It's at the top of the Disk Utility in the middle.

'10 - Type a new name for your hard drive (optional).\nType a new name for your hard drive (optional).  By default, the new SSD will retain the original name the manufacturer gave it.  If you want to give it a new name, type it in the box labeled "Name".'

'11 - Select "APFS" or "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".\nSelect "APFS" or "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)".  If you are using MacOS High Sierra, select APFS in the drop-down menu labeled "Format".  If you are using an older version of Mac OS, select "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)" from the drop-down menu.'
12 - Click Erase.\nClick Erase.  It's in the lower-right corner of the Disk Utility tool.  This erases the SSD and formats it.

'13 - Go to https:__www.shirt-pocket.com_SuperDuper_ in a web browser.\nGo to https://www.shirt-pocket.com/SuperDuper/ in a web browser.  SuperDuper is a simple and free program that allows you to clone your hard drive on Mac.'
'14 - Click Download.\nClick Download.  It\'s in the column on the right side of the page, below the bold text that says "Download Now".  This download the Super Duper installer.'

'15 - Install Super Duper.
Install Super Duper.  Use the following steps to install SuperDuper:
- Click "SuperDuper!.dmg" in your web browser or "Downloads" folder.
- Click Agree.
- Double-click SuperDuper!.app
- If you are asked if you are sure you want to open SuperDuper!.app, click Open.
- Click Install in "Applications".'
'16 - Open Super Duper.\nOpen Super Duper.  Super Duper opens automatically once it\'s installed.  If it is not currently open, you can open it in the "Applications" folder in the Finder.'
'17 - Select your Mac\'s current hard drive under "Copy".\nSelect your Mac\'s current hard drive under "Copy".  Use the drop-down menu under "Copy" to select your Mac\'s current hard drive.'
'18 - Select the SSD next to "to".\nSelect the SSD next to "to".  Use the drop-down menu next to "to" to select the SSD.'
'19 - Select "Back up - all files".\nSelect "Back up - all files".  Use the drop-down menu next to "using" to select "Back up - all files".'
'20 - Click Copy Now.\nClick Copy Now.  It\'s the blue button that appears at the bottom of Super Duper when you selected a "Copy" drive, and a "to" drive.'
'21 - Type your user password.\nType your user password.  You will need to type your user password in order to copy your hard drive over to a new SSD.'
22 - Click Copy.\nClick Copy.  This confirms that you want to copy the contents of your Mac's hard drive to a new SSD.  This process may take a few hours to complete.

'23 - Click Ok.
Click Ok.  This button appears once the cloning process is completed.[3]
- X
- Research source'

'24 - Install the SSD in your Mac.\nInstall the SSD in your Mac.  This process is different depending on your Mac model.  If you need assistance, take your Mac to an authorized Apple service provider.'
'0 - Burning an Audio CD'

'1 - Open iTunes.
Open iTunes. Create a new playlist by clicking File, then hovering the mouse over New. Select Playlist from the menu that appears.
- You can rename the playlist by clicking on the playlist name in the right frame after creating it. The playlist name will be the name of the CD, and will display when you insert the CD in a compatible reader.
- ;'

'2 - Add songs to your playlist.\nAdd songs to your playlist. Click and drag desired songs onto the playlist. You can also add an entire album at once by clicking and dragging on its cover image.\n- A standard audio CD can accommodate a max of 80 minutes of playback, meaning that your playlist should run at around 1.2 or 1.3 hours maximum. (This can be found at the bottom of the window.) Since this is an imprecise way of measuring, some 1.3-hr playlists will be shorter than 80 minutes and some will be longer. (You will find out for sure when you try to burn.)'

'3 - Rearrange the playlist order\nRearrange the playlist order if desired. There is a dropdown menu above the entries in your playlist, below the title. Select the method that you would like to sort the playlist. To put the songs in the order you want, click Manual Order and then click and drag the songs around inside the playlist.'

'4 - Insert a blank CD.
Insert a blank CD. Click File, then select Burn Playlist to Disc. If the playlist is too long, you will be given the option to spread it across multiple discs. You can do this if desired or cancel the burn and modify the playlist.
- If you’re not sure how to open the CD slot, go to Controls in the iTunes toolbar and click Eject Disc. This should open it regardless of whether or not there’s anything in there.
- You usually need to use a CD for audio discs. There are DVD audio players, but they are quite rare.'

'5 - Choose your burn settings.
Choose your burn settings. In iTunes 10 or earlier, the burn will begin automatically. In iTunes 11, you are given the option to adjust your burning preferences before the burn process begins.
- You can adjust the burn speed. Higher is faster, but very high speeds may cause disc errors on older systems or cheap CDs.
- You can choose whether or not to place a gap between songs.
- You can select your format. Audio CD is the most common and will work in virtually any CD player. MP3 CDs require special players to run. Only do this if you’re sure your player is compatible and all the songs on your playlist are MP3s (and not AACs, for example).'
'6 - Click Burn when ready.\nClick Burn when ready. The iTunes display will show the progress of the CD burn. iTunes will play an alert sound when the burn process is complete.'
'0 - Burning a Data CD'

'1 - Insert a blank CD-R or CD-RW into the CD drive.\nInsert a blank CD-R or CD-RW into the CD drive. A CD-R can be written to once, and then becomes read-only. A CD-RW can have data added and deleted.\n- These steps work for burning data DVDs as well as CDs, as long as your computer supports burning DVDs.'

'2 - Choose the Open Finder option.\nChoose the Open Finder option. When you insert a blank disc, you are typically asked how you would like to handle it on the computer. This option will open the Finder so you can easily drag and drop files when you select the CD'

'3 - Look for the icon of the blank CD that appears on your desktop.\nLook for the icon of the blank CD that appears on your desktop. It will be labeled “Untitled CD”. Double-click it to open the CD Finder window.'

'4 - Drag and drop the desired folders and files onto the CD.\nDrag and drop the desired folders and files onto the CD. Rename any files or folders that you want before you start the burn process. Once they are burned to the CD, you cannot change the names.'

'5 - Initiate the burn.\nInitiate the burn. Click File and then select “Burn Untitled CD”. You will be given the opportunity to name the CD. This name will appear whenever the CD is inserted into a computer.'

'6 - Click Burn after naming the CD.\nClick Burn after naming the CD. The files will then be saved onto the CD. This process can take anywhere from a minute to almost an hour depending on the size of the files you want to burn.\n- To reuse a CD-RW disc, erase all of the data on the disc and then repeat the burn process.'

column1: 'Were settings of disc image file changed?'
column4: '1 - Open the Disk Utility.\nOpen the Disk Utility. This can be found in the Utilities folder in your Applications. A disc image is a direct copy of a CD or DVD that is burned onto a blank CD or DVD. The burned disc will then act exactly like the original disc.'

column1: 'Were settings of disc image file changed?'
column4: '2 - Insert a blank disc.\nInsert a blank disc. Depending on the size of the image, insert either a CD or DVD. CD images are typically around 700 MB, DVD images can be as large as 4.7 GB.'

column1: 'Were settings of disc image file changed?'
column4: '3 - Add the disc image file.\nAdd the disc image file. Find your disc image file on your computer. The file should be in ISO format. Drag the ISO file into the sidebar of the Disk Utility window.'

column1: 'Were settings of disc image file changed?'
column4: '4 - Burn the disk.\nBurn the disk. After you drag the file into Disk Utility, click on the image in the sidebar, and then click the Burn button at the top of the window.'

'5 - Set your burn options.
Set your burn options. Once you click Burn, click the arrow button in the corner of the Burn window to open the burn options. Make sure that “Verify burned data” box is checked. Click Burn to start the burning process.[1]

'0 - Installing JDK'
'1 - Visit the JDK download page.\nVisit the JDK download page. Open your web browser and visit oracle.com/downloads/index.html.\n- ;'

'2 - Download the JDK installer.
Download the JDK installer. Once you're on the Downloads page, you'll need to navigate to the installer files:
- Click the "Java" option.
- Click "Java SE."
- Click the "Download" button next to "JDK 8 with NetBeans."
- Select "Accept License Agreement" and then click the download link for "Mac OS X" in the top section. This is the most recent release of the Java SDK with the NetBeans development environment.'
'3 - Double-click the downloaded installer.\nDouble-click the downloaded installer. The installer is in .dmg format. Double-clicking it will open the installation interface.'
4 - Follow the prompts to install the JDK.\nFollow the prompts to install the JDK. You'll be asked to enter your administrator password before installation can proceed.

5 - Delete the DMG file after installation (optional).
Delete the DMG file after installation (optional). This will help you save on disk space, since you don't need it after the JDK has been installed.[1]
- X
- Research source

'0 - Using Your Apple ID'

'1 - Try entering a wrong password three times.\nTry entering a wrong password three times. If you enabled this security feature when you first set up your account, you\'ll be able to use your Apple ID to reset your password. This only works if this feature is enabled to begin with.\n- If you have access to your Mac, you can turn this setting on by clicking the Apple menu and selecting "System Preferences." Click the "Users & Groups" option, then select your account. Click the padlock button to unlock the settings, then click "Allow user to reset password using Apple ID."'

2 - Click the link that appears to reset your password.\nClick the link that appears to reset your password. This will appear after entering your password incorrectly three times. If this option does not appear, this function has not been enabled for your account and you'll need to use another method in this article.

3 - Enter your Apple ID password.\nEnter your Apple ID password. To reset your admin password, you'll need to enter your Apple ID password. This is the Apple ID that is associated with your Mac user account.
4 - Create a new admin password.\nCreate a new admin password. After entering your Apple ID password, you'll be prompted to create a new admin password. You'll need to enter it twice to create it.

5 - Use your new password after rebooting.\nUse your new password after rebooting. You'll have to reboot your computer after creating a new admin password. Once your computer reboots, enter the new password you created to log in.

6 - Create a new Keychain.
Create a new Keychain. When you log in after using your new password, you'll likely be prompted that your Keychain cannot be accessed. This is because the Keychain is only secured with your original admin password, and cannot be accessed with the new password for security reasons. You'll need to create a new Keychain for your passwords.[3]
- X
- Research source
'0 - Changing Your Password if You Know It'

'1 - Click the Apple menu and select "System Preferences."\nClick the Apple menu and select "System Preferences." This will open your system settings. This method will only work for changing a password when you know the original. If you can\'t remember your password, use one of the other methods in this article.'
'2 - Select "Users & Groups."\nSelect "Users & Groups." This will allow you to change settings for the users on your computer.'

'3 - Click the padlock in the lower-left corner and enter your current password.\nClick the padlock in the lower-left corner and enter your current password. This will allow you to make changes to the settings.'
'4 - Select your user account and click "Change Password."\nSelect your user account and click "Change Password." A new window will appear for you to change your password in.'
'5 - Enter your old password in the first field.\nEnter your old password in the first field. This is the password you are currently using.'
'6 - Create a new password.\nCreate a new password. You\'ll need to enter it twice to verify it. Click "Change Password" to save it.'

7 - Add a hint (optional).\nAdd a hint (optional). You can add a hint for your password that can be displayed if you are having trouble logging in. This is recommended so that you don't have to go through the trouble of resetting your password if you ever forget it.
8 - Start using your new password immediately.\nStart using your new password immediately. Your password will be applied immediately, and you'll use it whenever you're prompted for your password.

'0 - Steps'

'1 - In the search bar, search for the application called "Activity Monitor" and open it.\nIn the search bar, search for the application called "Activity Monitor" and open it. Make sure the application that you need to un-pause is listed.\n- ;'
'2 - Go "View > Columns > Process ID".\nGo "View > Columns > Process ID". This will bring up a new column called PID that has numbers in it.'
'3 - Find the number listed in the PID column, of the application you need to unpause.\nFind the number listed in the PID column, of the application you need to unpause.'
'4 - In the search bar, search for the application "Terminal" and open it.\nIn the search bar, search for the application "Terminal" and open it.'

'5 - In the text area of Terminal type the code "kill -CONT 155".\nIn the text area of Terminal type the code "kill -CONT 155". Replacing the \'155\' with the PID number of the application you want to un-pause.'

'6 - Press the enter key and wait for the application to start responding again, this could take a couple of seconds.\nPress the enter key and wait for the application to start responding again, this could take a couple of seconds.'
'0 - Preparing to Clear the Cache'
1 - Open the Calendar app.\nOpen the Calendar app. Double-click the calendar icon in your Mac's Dock.\n- ;

2 - Back up your calendar's data.
Back up your calendar's data. If you have multiple calendars synced to different accounts, you'll need to back those up, too. To do so:[1]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- Click File
- Select Export
- Click Calendar Archive
- Select a save location.

3 - Try removing and re-adding the account.
Try removing and re-adding the account. You may be able to solve your calendar problem by removing the calendar account from your computer and then adding it back. To do so:
- Click the Apple Menu 
- Click System Preferences
- Click Internet Accounts
- Select the calendar's account.
- Click -
- Restart your Mac
- Go back to the Internet Accounts page.
- Select an account provider (e.g., Outlook).
- Enter your account's email address and password.
'4 - Close and re-open your Calendar.\nClose and re-open your Calendar. If the problem was fixed, your account simply needed a refresh. If not, continue to the next step.'

5 - Double-check your backups before clearing your cache.\nDouble-check your backups before clearing your cache. There is a decent chance that your calendars' contents will be completely deleted if you clear your cache, so make absolutely sure that you have a backup file for each of your calendars. Only proceed after you are certain that you won't lose anything important.
6 - Close your Calendar app.\nClose your Calendar app. You are now ready to proceed with clearing your calendar's cache.

'0 - Clearing the Cache'
'1 - Open Finder.\nOpen Finder. Click the blue, face-shaped app in the Dock.'
'2 - Select your Mac\'s hard drive.\nSelect your Mac\'s hard drive. It\'s on the left side of the Finder window, just below the "Devices" heading.'
'3 - Double-click the Macintosh HD folder.\nDouble-click the Macintosh HD folder. You should see this option near the top of the Finder window.'
'4 - Double-click the Users folder.\nDouble-click the Users folder. This will open the Users folder.'
'5 - Double-click the folder with your name on it.\nDouble-click the folder with your name on it. This is the personal user folder.'
'6 - Press ⌘ Command+⇧ Shift+.. Doing so prompts the hidden folders that are in your personal user folder to display. One such folder is the Library folder.'
'Press ⌘ Command+⇧ Shift+.. Doing so prompts the hidden folders that are in your personal user folder to display. One such folder is the Library folder.'
7 - Double-click the Library folder.\nDouble-click the Library folder. It's in the middle of the personal user folder.
'8 - Double-click the Calendars folder.\nDouble-click the Calendars folder. This folder is in the middle of the Library folder.'

'9 - Delete any cache files in this folder.\nDelete any cache files in this folder. There may be several files with "Cache" in their title; select each cache file by holding ⌘ Command and clicking them, then click File and click Move to Trash.\n- These cache files are often named things like com.apple.cal.'
10 - Click the Trash icon.\nClick the Trash icon. It's a waste basket-shaped icon in the Dock. A pop-up menu will appear.
'11 - Click Empty Trash….\nClick Empty Trash…. This option is in the pop-up menu.'

'12 - Click Empty Trash when prompted.\nClick Empty Trash when prompted. Doing so will most likely trigger an error message that says "The operation can\'t be completed because the item \'[cache file name]\' is in use", meaning you\'ll need to force-quit the Calendar background process and then empty Trash again.\n- If you don\'t see any error messages pop up, your Calendar app\'s cache has successfully been cleared.'

10 - Click the Trash icon.\nClick the Trash icon. It's a waste basket-shaped icon in the Dock. A pop-up menu will appear.

Doing so will most likely trigger an error message that says "The operation can\'t be completed because the item \'[cache file name]\' is in use", meaning you\'ll need to force-quit the Calendar background process and then empty Trash again.\n- If you don\'t see any error messages pop up, your Calendar app\'s cache has successfully been cleared.'
'0 - Force-Quitting Calendar'
'1 - Click Continue on the error window.\nClick Continue on the error window. You may have to do this for several errors depending on how many files you tried to delete.'
'2 - Open Spotlight .\nOpen Spotlight . Click the magnifying glass-shaped icon in the top-right corner of the screen.'

'3 - Type activity monitor into Spotlight.\nType activity monitor into Spotlight. Doing so searches your Mac for the Activity Monitor app, which is a program that allows you to monitor and halt background processes.'
4 - Click Activity Monitor.\nClick Activity Monitor. It's a black box with green lines on it. You should see it near the top of the Spotlight drop-down menu.
'5 - Double-click the "CalendarAgent" entry.\nDouble-click the "CalendarAgent" entry. This is the Calendar background process. It will open.'
6 - Click Quit.\nClick Quit. It's in the bottom-right side of the Calendar window.

'7 - Click Force Quit when prompted.\nClick Force Quit when prompted. Doing so will prevent the Calendar background process from running, meaning that you can delete the cache files without interference.\n- You may not see the "CalendarAgent" entry disappear from the Activity Manager when you click Force Quit.'

8 - Empty the Trash.\nEmpty the Trash. Click the Trash Can icon, click Empty Trash..., and click Empty Trash when prompted. You shouldn't experience any errors this time, meaning that your calendar's cached files will be deleted. You have successfully cleared your Mac's Calendar app's cache.

Doing so will prevent the Calendar background process from running, meaning that you can delete the cache files without interference.\n- You may not see the "CalendarAgent" entry disappear from the Activity Manager when you click Force Quit.'

8 - Empty the Trash.\nEmpty the Trash. Click the Trash Can icon, click Empty Trash..., and click Empty Trash when prompted. You shouldn't experience any errors this time, meaning that your calendar's cached files will be deleted. You have successfully cleared your Mac's Calendar app's cache.

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4: 1 - Open up the screenshot you took.\nOpen up the screenshot you took. By default, it should open in Mac's Preview app.\n- ;

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4: '2 - Click the small pencil icon in the top menu.\nClick the small pencil icon in the top menu. The pencil icon is the last icon at the top menu and opens up the Annotation menu, directly under the top menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4: '3 - Click the small arrow or line icon and select the arrow option from the drop-down menu.\nClick the small arrow or line icon and select the arrow option from the drop-down menu. On some versions of Preview, the two options are separate, but on newest versions, you find the arrow by clicking the line icon and then adjusting the line style to one with an arrow on one side.\n- You can also select the lines option, and make an arrow with three strokes of the lines.'

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4:
4 - Click, hold, and drag until the arrow is pointing to the right spot you want it to.
Click, hold, and drag until the arrow is pointing to the right spot you want it to. Make sure the arrow is pointing where it's supposed to point. Let go of your mouse button when you're done.
- To adjust the location of the arrow, you can click and drag to move it around the image.
- To change the length or angle of the arrow, you can click on one end of the arrow and hold your mouse down while adjusting the arrow.
- You can also change the color and thickness/style of the arrow from the menu bar by clicking on the relevant icons and making your selections.

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4: '5 - Click the pencil icon again.\nClick the pencil icon again. This will remove the bottom menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of small arrow or line icon changed?'
column4: '6 - Save your screenshot.\nSave your screenshot. When you show or add the screenshot to someone, the arrow will be there.'
'0 - Steps'
'1 - Open Automator.\nOpen Automator. You can click on it in Launchpad, or double click on it in the Applications folder.\n- ;'
'2 - Select "Workflow".\nSelect "Workflow". Then click "Choose".'
'3 - Click on "Files & Folders" in the first column, inside "Library".\nClick on "Files & Folders" in the first column, inside "Library".'
'4 - Drag the files you want to rename into the upper right of the Automator window'

Drag the files you want to rename into the upper right of the Automator window\n- It's recommended to make copies of a couple files and do a test run on these files first, in case things don't turn out how you want them to.
'5 - Double click on "Rename Finder Items" in the second column.\nDouble click on "Rename Finder Items" in the second column.'

'6 - Decide if you want Automator to make copies of your files.\nDecide if you want Automator to make copies of your files. If so, click "Add," or if not, click "Don\'t Add."\n- The rest of the steps in this tutorial are based on clicking "Don\'t Add" in this step.'

'7 - Decide if you want to add or replace any text in the file names.\nDecide if you want to add or replace any text in the file names. Select "Add Text" or "Replace Text" from the drop-down menu, accordingly.'

'8 - Add text, if desired.\nAdd text, if desired. Just type it into the text box.\n- If you are adding text, select "after name" or "before name" or "as extension". Selecting "after name" will add the text at the end of the file name and in front of the file type extension.'

'9 - Replace text, if desired.\nReplace text, if desired. Type in the text you are searching for, and then type in the text you want to replace it with.\n- If you are replacing text, select "full name" or "basename only" or extension only". And if you want uppercase and lowercase letters to be matched uncheck "Ignore Case".'

'10 - Click the "Run" button in the upper right corner of the Automator window.\nClick the "Run" button in the upper right corner of the Automator window. If you are making just one change to your file names, that\'s the last step. The names of your files should now be changed.'

'11 - Continue if you have multiple changes to make.\nContinue if you have multiple changes to make. If you are making more than one change to the file names, such as adding text to the beginning of the file names and adding text to the end of the file names, click these 2 Xs to close these 2 windows inside Automator. Then re-drag your files into Automator.'

'0 - Using Recovery Mode'

1 - Reboot your computer.\nReboot your computer. If you can't change your password using your Apple ID, you can use Recovery Mode to reset it. Recovery Mode needs to be accessed as your computer is starting up.\n- ;

'2 - Hold .
Hold .⌘ Command+R as soon as you hear the chime. Continue holding the keys until you see the loading bar appear. This will boot your Mac into Recovery Mode. It may take a while to load.[1]
- X
- Research source'
'3 - Click the "Utilities" menu and select "Terminal."\nClick the "Utilities" menu and select "Terminal." You\'ll see the Utilities menu in the bar at the top of the screen.'
'4 - Type .\nType .resetpassword and press ⏎ Return. This will open the Reset Password utility.'

'5 - Select your hard drive.\nSelect your hard drive. If you have multiple drives in your Mac, you\'ll need to select the one that your operating system is on. This will typically be labeled "Macintosh HD."'
'6 - Select the user account you want to change the password for.\nSelect the user account you want to change the password for. Use the drop-down menu to select your user account.'
'7 - Create a new admin password.\nCreate a new admin password. Enter your new admin password twice to create it.'
8 - Enter an optional password hint.\nEnter an optional password hint. This hint can be displayed if you're having difficulty logging in.
'9 - Click "Save" to save your new password.\nClick "Save" to save your new password. It will be applied when you reboot your computer.'

'10 - Click the Apple menu and select "OS X Utilities" → "Quit OS X Utilities."\nClick the Apple menu and select "OS X Utilities" → "Quit OS X Utilities." Opt to restart your Mac when prompted. This will reboot your computer and apply your new password.'

'11 - Log in with your new password.
Log in with your new password. After rebooting, select your user account and log in with your new password.[2]
- X
- Research source'

Hold .⌘ Command+R as soon as you hear the chime. Continue holding the keys until you see the loading bar appear. This will boot your Mac into Recovery Mode. It may take a while to load.[1]
- X
- Research source'

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: '3 - Click the "Utilities" menu and select "Terminal."\nClick the "Utilities" menu and select "Terminal." You\'ll see the Utilities menu in the bar at the top of the screen.'

column4: '4 - Type .\nType .resetpassword and press ⏎ Return. This will open the Reset Password utility.'

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: '5 - Select your hard drive.\nSelect your hard drive. If you have multiple drives in your Mac, you\'ll need to select the one that your operating system is on. This will typically be labeled "Macintosh HD."'

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: '6 - Select the user account you want to change the password for.\nSelect the user account you want to change the password for. Use the drop-down menu to select your user account.'

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: '7 - Create a new admin password.\nCreate a new admin password. Enter your new admin password twice to create it.'

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: 8 - Enter an optional password hint.\nEnter an optional password hint. This hint can be displayed if you're having difficulty logging in.

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: '9 - Click "Save" to save your new password.\nClick "Save" to save your new password. It will be applied when you reboot your computer.'

column1: 'Were settings of new admin password changed?'
column4: '10 - Click the Apple menu and select "OS X Utilities" → "Quit OS X Utilities."\nClick the Apple menu and select "OS X Utilities" → "Quit OS X Utilities." Opt to restart your Mac when prompted. This will reboot your computer and apply your new password.'

'0 - Allowing a Program'

'1 - Download the software as you normally would from the Internet.\nDownload the software as you normally would from the Internet. If asked if you want to "keep" or "discard" the file, select keep. Note that you should only do this if you are certain you trust the publisher of the software.\n- ;'

'2 - Open your software\'s setup file.\nOpen your software\'s setup file. This will prompt a pop-up with an error message that says "[Name] can\'t be opened because it was not downloaded from the App Store."'
'3 - Click OK.\nClick OK. This will close the pop-up window.'
'4 - Open the Apple menu .\nOpen the Apple menu . Click the Apple logo in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.'
'5 - Click System Preferences.\nClick System Preferences. This option is near the top of the drop-down menu.'
6 - Click Security & Privacy.\nClick Security & Privacy. It's near the top of the System Preferences window.
7 - Click the lock icon.\nClick the lock icon. It's in the bottom-left corner of the window.
'8 - Enter your password, then click Unlock.\nEnter your password, then click Unlock. This will allow you to edit items in this menu.'
9 - Click Open Anyway.\nClick Open Anyway. It's next to your file's name.
'10 - Click Open when prompted.\nClick Open when prompted. Doing so will open your file and continue with the installation.'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4: '0 - Setting Up OS X'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4: '1 - Set up the keyboard.\nSet up the keyboard. The first thing you will be asked to do after the computer restarts is to set up the keyboard. Follow the on-screen prompts to detect and setup the keyboard.'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4: '2 - Set your region and keyboard layout.\nSet your region and keyboard layout. After the keyboard has been detected, you will be asked to set your region and choose your keyboard layout. If you take the computer traveling often, set the region to your home region.'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4: '3 - Choose whether or not you want to transfer data.\nChoose whether or not you want to transfer data. Since you performed a clean installation, there will be no data to import. You will be copying your old backed-up files over later. Choose "Do not transfer my information now" and click Continue.'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4: '4 - Enter your Apple ID.\nEnter your Apple ID. If you have an Apple ID, you can use it to log in. This will sync your settings with your other Apple devices. See this guide for details on creating an Apple ID. Entering an Apple ID is optional.\n- You can also choose whether or not you want to register your software with Apple. This can help you if you need to get official support.'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4:
'5 - Create an administrator account.
Create an administrator account. The administrator account is the account that has permission to change system settings and install software. If the computer is yours, enter your name in the "Name" field, and a nickname in the "Short Name" field. Oftentimes users will simply use a lowercase version of their name in the "Short Name" field.
- Your Short Name is used to label your Home directory.
- It is very difficult to change your Short Name later, so make sure you're happy with it.
- The administrator account needs a password. You can add a password hint if you'd like as well.'

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4: 6 - Start using OS X.\nStart using OS X. Once the Setup Assistant has finished, you're ready to begin using your newly-installed operating system. You will need to reinstall any programs you had before, and you can copy back your old backed-up files to your User folders.

column1: 'Were settings of region and keyboard layout changed?'
column4:
'7 - Install any available updates.
Install any available updates. After OS X has finished installing, you'll want to install all the available updates as quickly as possible. these help secure your system and can improve performance. You will need to download the updates from Apple, so your computer will need to be connected to the internet.[3]
- X
- Research source
- 
- 
- To get the latest updates, click the Apple menu and select "Software Update...". The tool will check for any available updates and then display them. Select all of the updates you want to install and click Install button. The updates will be downloaded from the Apple servers and then installed. You will need to reboot after installation has finished.
- Repeat the process. Some updates only become available after other updates have been installed. Keep checking for and installing updates until there are none left.'

column4: '1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the dock changed?'
column4: '2 - Select "System Preferences."\nSelect "System Preferences."'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the dock changed?'
column4: '3 - Click the "Dock" option.\nClick the "Dock" option. You\'ll find this in the top row of options. If you\'re not in the main System Preferences menu, click the "Show All" button at the top of the window.'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the dock changed?'
column4: '4 - Check the "Automatically hide and show the Dock" box.\nCheck the "Automatically hide and show the Dock" box. This will immediately hide the dock at the bottom of the screen.'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the dock changed?'
column4: '5 - Move your mouse to the bottom of the screen.\nMove your mouse to the bottom of the screen. This will reveal the Dock.'

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: '0 - Backing up Your Mac'

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: 1 - Click Disk Utility.\nClick Disk Utility. It's in the middle of the Recovery window.

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: '2 - Click Continue.\nClick Continue. This option is in the bottom-right corner of the window. Doing so opens the Disk Utility window.'

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: 3 - Select your external hard drive.\nSelect your external hard drive. Click your external hard drive's name or letter in the left-hand side of the window.

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: '4 - Click Edit.\nClick Edit. This menu item is in the upper-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.'

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: 5 - Click Restore….\nClick Restore…. It's in the drop-down menu. This will open a pop-up window.

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: '6 - Select your Mac\'s hard drive.\nSelect your Mac\'s hard drive. Click the "Restore from" drop-down box, then click your Mac\'s hard drive\'s name in the resulting drop-down menu.'

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: 7 - Click Restore.\nClick Restore. It's a blue button on the right side of the window. This will prompt your Mac's hard drive's contents to begin copying over to your external hard drive.

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: 8 - Wait for the copying to finish.\nWait for the copying to finish. When prompted, you're free to restart your Mac and begin using it like usual.

column1: Were settings of mac 's hard drive changed?
column4: 9 - Eject your external hard drive\nEject your external hard drive. This will ensure that the information stored on the drive doesn't accidentally get corrupted.

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4: '0 - Steps'

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4:
1 - Download your preferred web browser.
Download your preferred web browser. If you don't already have the web browser that you want to use installed on your Mac, you'll need to download it before proceeding:
- 
- Google Chrome - Go to Chrome's download page and click the blue DOWNLOAD CHROME button.
- Firefox - Go to Firefox's download page and click the green Download Now button.
- Opera - Go to Opera's download page and click the green Download now button.
- ;

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4:
2 - Install your browser.
Install your browser. To do so:
- Double-click the downloaded DMG file.
- Follow any on-screen prompts if available.
- Click and drag the browser's icon onto the Applications folder shortcut.
- Hold down Control while clicking the DMG window.
- Click Eject in the drop-down menu.

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4: '3 - Open the Apple menu .\nOpen the Apple menu . Click the Apple logo in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.'

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4: 4 - Click System Preferences….\nClick System Preferences…. It's near the top of the drop-down menu. Doing so opens the System Preferences window.

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4:
'5 - Click General.
Click General. This option is near the top-left corner of the System Preferences window. You can change your web browser from here.[1]
- X
- Research source'

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4: '6 - Click the "Default web browser" drop-down box.\nClick the "Default web browser" drop-down box. It\'s in the middle of the page. Doing so prompts a drop-down menu.'

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4: 7 - Select a browser.\nSelect a browser. In the drop-down menu, click a browser that you want to use. As long as the browser is installed on your computer and is up to date, it should show up as an option here.\n- If you don't see the browser that you want to use, restart your Mac and then re-open the System Preferences window to try again.

column1: 'Were settings of default web browser changed?'
column4: '8 - Exit the System Preferences window.\nExit the System Preferences window. Your settings will be saved; any links or app extensions should now open in your new default browser.'
'0 - Using Terminal'

1 - Open the Terminal utility.\nOpen the Terminal utility. By default, this is in the Utilities folder, located in the Applications folder.\n- If a normal Force Quit doesn't work, you may need to use this method to end the program.
'2 - Type "top" and press ⏎ Return.\nType "top" and press ⏎ Return. The “top” command displays information about the applications that are currently running.'

'3 - Find the program you want to close.\nFind the program you want to close. Under the column titled "COMMAND", find the name of the application you wish to quit.\n- The COMMAND list may use a truncated name for the program. Look for a name that looks similar to the program you are trying to close.'
'4 - Find the PID (Process ID).\nFind the PID (Process ID). Once you find the name of program, find the number to the immediate left of it, under the PID column. Make a note of the PID number.'
'5 - Type "q".\nType "q". This will exit the list of applications and return you to the command line.'

'6 - Type "kill ###".\nType "kill ###". Replace the "###" with the number from the PID Column you just located. For example: If you were trying to quit iTunes, and found iTunes to have PID number 3703, you would type "kill 3703".\n- If the program does not respond to the “kill” command, type “sudo kill -9 ###”, replacing ### with the PID number.'
'7 - Exit the terminal.\nExit the terminal. The application should quit and you can be relaunched.'
'0 - Using Terminal'

1 - Open the Terminal utility.\nOpen the Terminal utility. By default, this is in the Utilities folder, located in the Applications folder.\n- If a normal Force Quit doesn't work, you may need to use this method to end the program.
'2 - Type "top" and press ⏎ Return.\nType "top" and press ⏎ Return. The “top” command displays information about the applications that are currently running.'

'3 - Find the program you want to close.\nFind the program you want to close. Under the column titled "COMMAND", find the name of the application you wish to quit.\n- The COMMAND list may use a truncated name for the program. Look for a name that looks similar to the program you are trying to close.'
'4 - Find the PID (Process ID).\nFind the PID (Process ID). Once you find the name of program, find the number to the immediate left of it, under the PID column. Make a note of the PID number.'
'5 - Type "q".\nType "q". This will exit the list of applications and return you to the command line.'

'6 - Type "kill ###".\nType "kill ###". Replace the "###" with the number from the PID Column you just located. For example: If you were trying to quit iTunes, and found iTunes to have PID number 3703, you would type "kill 3703".\n- If the program does not respond to the “kill” command, type “sudo kill -9 ###”, replacing ### with the PID number.'
'7 - Exit the terminal.\nExit the terminal. The application should quit and you can be relaunched.'

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: '0 - Using QuickTime'

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: 1 - Open the video you want to record on YouTube.\nOpen the video you want to record on YouTube. Don't play the video just yet—just bring it up on the screen so it's ready.\n- ;

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: '2 - Open QuickTime on your Mac.\nOpen QuickTime on your Mac. It\'s the gray-and-blue "Q" icon on the Launchpad and in the Applications folder.'

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: 3 - Click the File menu.\nClick the File menu. It's at the top-left corner of the screen in the menu bar.

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: 4 - Click New Screen Recording on the menu.\nClick New Screen Recording on the menu. This opens the Screen Recording window.\n- Depending on the version of macOS you're using, you may see a toolbar with several icons on it instead.

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4:
5 - Select Internal Microphone from the menu.
Select Internal Microphone from the menu. The menu is the downward-pointing arrow to the right of the red circle at the center of the window. This ensures that the app captures the video's sound.[1]
- X
- Research source
- 
- If you don't see such a menu, click Options instead.

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: 6 - Click the red circle button.\nClick the red circle button. You'll see some quick instructions about selecting an area of the screen to record.

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: '7 - Drag the crosshairs over to select the video.\nDrag the crosshairs over to select the video. This tells QuickTime to only capture the video rather than the entire screen.'

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4: 8 - Click Record and start playing the video.\nClick Record and start playing the video. If the sound isn't on, be sure to turn it on now.

column1: 'Were settings of new screen recording changed?'
column4:
9 - Click the Stop Recording icon when the video is finished.
Click the Stop Recording icon when the video is finished. It's on the menu at the top of the screen and looks like a black circle with a white square inside.[2]
- X
- Research source
- 
-  QuickTime will stop recording the screen and display the finished recording, which is also saved to your Movies folder.
- If you want to trim the beginning and/or end from the recording, click the Edit menu and select Trim. You can then drag the yellow trimming bar to select the part of the video you want to keep and click Trim to save your changes.
'0 - Using ClipGrab'

1 - Go to https:__clipgrab.org and click Free Download.
Go to https://clipgrab.org and click Free Download. ClipGrab is a free Mac app that lets you save YouTube videos to your computer.[5]
- X
- Research source
- 
-  ClipGrab is a good alternative to QuickTime because you won't have to sit through the video while it records—you'll just enter the URL and the app does the work.

2 - Open the ClipGrab installer.\nOpen the ClipGrab installer. You should be able to click its name at the bottom of your browser. If you don't see it, double-click the installer in your Downloads folder.
'3 - Drag the ClipGrab icon to the Applications folder to install.\nDrag the ClipGrab icon to the Applications folder to install.'
4 - Open ClipGrab once the installation is finished.\nOpen ClipGrab once the installation is finished. It'll be in the Applications folder.
5 - Click the Downloads tab in ClipGrab.\nClick the Downloads tab in ClipGrab. It's near the top of the window.

6 - Copy the address of the YouTube video you want to download.\nCopy the address of the YouTube video you want to download. If you haven't already done so, bring up the video in your favorite web browser now. To copy the URL, click the address bar to highlight it, and then press ⌘ Command+C to copy.
'7 - Paste the copied URL into ClipGrab.\nPaste the copied URL into ClipGrab. To do this, click back over to ClipGrab, click the typing area, and then press ⌘ Command+V to paste.'
'8 - Select MPEG4 from the "Format" menu.\nSelect MPEG4 from the "Format" menu. If you have a different video file preference, choose that instead.'
9 - Click Grab this clip.\nClick Grab this clip. It's below the URL you pasted into the blank. ClipGrab will download the YouTube video to your computer's default Downloads folder.
'0 - Using Unarchiver'

'1 - Download the Unarchiver application.
Download the Unarchiver application. The Unarchiver is an app that allows you to open RAR files on your Mac. To download it, do the following:
- Open your Mac's  App Store
- Click the search bar in the upper-right side of the App Store window.
- Type unarchiver into the search bar, then press ⏎ Return.
- Click Get below the "Unarchiver" heading.
- Click Install App below the "Unarchiver" heading when prompted.
- Enter your Apple ID password if prompted.
- ;'
2 - Open Launchpad.\nOpen Launchpad. Click the Launchpad icon, which resembles a rocket ship. It's usually found in the Dock at the bottom of your Mac's screen.

'3 - Click The Unarchiver application.\nClick The Unarchiver application. This will launch the Unarchiver program.\n- If prompted, you may have to select whether you want to save unarchived files to the same folder each time, or if you want to be asked each time.'
4 - Click the Archive Formats tab.\nClick the Archive Formats tab. It's at the top of the window.
'5 - Check the "RAR Archive" box.\nCheck the "RAR Archive" box. Doing so ensures that the Unarchiver program will be able to open RAR files in the future.'

'6 - Select a RAR file.\nSelect a RAR file. Go to the location of a RAR file which you want to open, then click the RAR file.\n- If you are trying to extract a multi-part RAR file, start with the ".rar" or ".part001.rar" file. All the parts should be in the same folder.'

7 - Click File.\nClick File. It's at the top of your Mac's screen. A drop-down menu will appear.\n- In some cases, you may also be able to double-click the RAR file to open it in Unarchiver. This may not work if you have multiple apps which can open RAR files on your Mac.
'8 - Select Open With.\nSelect Open With. This option is in the File drop-down menu. A pop-out will appear.'

9 - Click The Unarchiver.\nClick The Unarchiver. It's in the pop-out menu. Doing so will prompt your RAR file to open in Unarchiver, which will begin extracting the RAR file's contents into the RAR's folder.\n- If the RAR file is password-protected, you'll be prompted to enter the password before the files can be extracted.

10 - Open the extracted file(s).\nOpen the extracted file(s). By default, The Unarchiver will extract the RAR's files into the same folder in which the RAR file was located. For example, if the RAR file was in the Desktop folder, you'll find the extracted files there.

'0 - Using StuffIt Expander'

1 - Open the StuffIt Expander website.\nOpen the StuffIt Expander website. Go to http://my.smithmicro.com/stuffit-expander-mac.html in your computer's web browser. StuffIt Expander is a free application that supports a wide variety of archive files, including RAR.

'2 - Download StuffIt Expander.
Download StuffIt Expander. To do so:
- Enter your email address in the "Email*" field.
- Click FREE Download
- Click Download'

'3 - Install StuffIt Expander.\nInstall StuffIt Expander. Double-click the downloaded DMG file, click Agree when prompted, and wait for it to install.\n- You may be prompted to verify the software before you can install it.'
'4 - Open StuffIt Expander.\nOpen StuffIt Expander. Double-click the StuffIt Expander app icon to do so.\n- If prompted, click Open.'
'5 - Click Move to Applications Folder.\nClick Move to Applications Folder. This will finish installing and opening StuffIt Expander; you should now be able to use this app to open RAR files.'
'6 - Click StuffIt Expander.\nClick StuffIt Expander. This menu item is in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.'
7 - Click Preferences….\nClick Preferences…. You'll find it in the StuffIt Expander drop-down menu.
8 - Click the Advanced tab.\nClick the Advanced tab. It's at the top of the Preferences window.
9 - Scroll down and click RAR.\nScroll down and click RAR. You'll find this option in the middle of the window.
10 - Click Assign to StuffIt Expander.\nClick Assign to StuffIt Expander. It's on the right side of the window. Doing so allows StuffIt Expander to open RAR files on your Mac.
'11 - Close the window.\nClose the window. Click the red button in the upper-left corner of the window to do so.'

Double-click a RAR file. Doing so should launch StuffIt Expander, which will begin extracting the RAR's files.

- If you are trying to extract a multi-part RAR file, start with the ".rar" or ".part001.rar" file. All the parts should be in the same folder.
- If the RAR file is password-protected, you'll be prompted to enter the password before the files can be extracted.'

13 - Open the extracted file(s).\nOpen the extracted file(s). By default, StuffIt Expander will extract the files into the same folder in which the RAR file was located. For example, if the RAR file was in the Desktop folder, you'll find the extracted files there.
'0 - Clearing the System Cache'

'1 - Close as many open programs as possible.\nClose as many open programs as possible. Open programs use files from the "Cache" folder, so you won\'t be able to remove as many cached files as you like if you have multiple programs open.\n- ;'
2 - Go to your Mac's Finder.\nGo to your Mac's Finder. Do this by clicking on your Desktop image or on the blue smiley-face icon on the far left in your Dock.
3 - Click Go.\nClick Go. It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.
4 - Click Go to Folder….\nClick Go to Folder…. You'll find this option near the bottom of the Go drop-down menu. Doing so opens a text box.
'5 - Enter the "Library" folder path.\nEnter the "Library" folder path. Type ~/Library/ into the text box.'
'6 - Click Go.\nClick Go. It\'s a blue button in the bottom-right corner of the text box. This will open the Library folder, in which you should find a folder named "Caches".'
'7 - Double-click the "Caches" folder.\nDouble-click the "Caches" folder. This folder should be near the top of the Finder window, but scroll down to find it if it isn\'t there.'

'8 - Select the "Caches" folder\'s contents.\nSelect the "Caches" folder\'s contents. Click one item or folder in the "Caches" folder, then press ⌘ Command+A. Doing so selects everything in the "Caches" folder.'

'9 - Delete the "Caches" folder\'s contents.\nDelete the "Caches" folder\'s contents. Click the File menu item at the top of the screen, then click Move Items to Trash in the drop-down menu. The "Caches" folder\'s contents will be moved to the Trash.\n- If you receive an error telling you that one or more of the files can\'t be deleted, they\'re being used by a program that\'s currently open. Skip deleting these files for now, then try deleting them later when the programs in question aren\'t open.'
10 - Click Finder.\nClick Finder. It's a menu item in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.
'11 - Click Empty Trash….\nClick Empty Trash…. This option is in the Finder drop-down menu.'
'12 - Click OK when prompted.\nClick OK when prompted. Doing so will empty the trash, thus completely clearing the cache files from your Mac.'

'0 - Clearing the Safari Cache'
1 - Open Safari.\nOpen Safari. The Safari app icon resembles a blue compass, and can usually be found in your Mac's Dock at the bottom of the screen.

'2 - Click Safari.\nClick Safari. It\'s a menu item in the top-left corner of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.\n- If you see a Develop menu item in the bar at the top of the screen, click it instead, then skip ahead to the "Click Empty Caches" step.'
3 - Click Preferences….\nClick Preferences…. It's near the top of the Safari drop-down menu. A new window will open.
4 - Click the Advanced tab.\nClick the Advanced tab. You'll find it on the far right side of the Preferences window.

'5 - Check the "Show Develop menu in menu bar" box.\nCheck the "Show Develop menu in menu bar" box. It\'s at the bottom of the Preferences window. This adds the Develop tab to the menu bar for Safari.'
6 - Click Develop.\nClick Develop. It's an option in the menu bar at the top of the screen. A drop-down menu will appear.

7 - Click Empty Caches.\nClick Empty Caches. You'll see it in the Develop drop-down menu. Doing so will automatically clear your Mac's Safari cache.\n- You won't see a pop-up window or a confirmation notice when the cache is cleared.

'1 - Download the image or video.\nDownload the image or video. Gifs work too.\n- ;'
'2 - Open Photo Booth.\nOpen Photo Booth.'
'3 - Click the "Effects" button located at the bottom right corner of the Photo Booth.\nClick the "Effects" button located at the bottom right corner of the Photo Booth.'
'4 - Go to the last page in "Effects".\nGo to the last page in "Effects".'

'5 - Drag the background that you downloaded (or have) to any box marked "User Backdrop".\nDrag the background that you downloaded (or have) to any box marked "User Backdrop".\n- The background will change to the image or video that is dragged. If it\'s a video it will play after you select the user backdrop.'
'6 - Select the user backdrop.\nSelect the user backdrop.'
'0 - Enabling Automatic Updates'

'1 - Open the Apple menu and select "System Preferences."
Open the Apple menu and select "System Preferences." You can turn on automatic updates for apps and system updates so that you never have to check for them yourself. This will help keep your software up-to-date and secure.[2]
- X
- Research source
- 
- You'll find the Apple menu in the upper-left corner of the screen.'
'2 - Click the "App Store" option.\nClick the "App Store" option. This will open the App Store settings.'
'3 - Check the "Automatically check for updates" box.\nCheck the "Automatically check for updates" box. This will enable the various automatic update options.'

'4 - Check all four boxes underneath "Automatically check for updates."\nCheck all four boxes underneath "Automatically check for updates." This will automatically check for, download, and install app updates, system updates, and security updates once a day.'

'5 - Click "Check Now" to see if any new updates are available.\nClick "Check Now" to see if any new updates are available. If any updates are available, they will start downloading and installing immediately'
'0 - Installing Updates in Legacy OS X Versions'
'1 - Open the Apple menu and select "Software Update."\nOpen the Apple menu and select "Software Update." This will open a new window that will check for any available system updates.'

'2 - Manage your software update preferences.
Manage your software update preferences. You can choose a schedule for the frequency at which you want software updates to occur, or you can choose to have updates checked and installed automatically when they become available.
- Select "Check for updates," then select how often you want to check for them. You can check on a daily, weekly, or on a monthly basis.
- Select "Download updates automatically" if you want your computer to automatically check and install updates when they become available. You may be required to restart your computer when the updates are completed.'
'3 - Click the "Check Now" button.\nClick the "Check Now" button. This will check for any available updates for your system software and Apple programs.'

4 - Check the box for each update you want to install.\nCheck the box for each update you want to install. After checking for updates, you'll be presented with a list of updates that you can install. Each one will have a checkbox next to it. Check the box for each update you want to download and install.

'5 - Click the "Install # Items" button.\nClick the "Install # Items" button. You\'ll be prompted for the administrator password. Once you enter the password, the updates will begin downloading and installing.'

'6 - Open the App Store to check for app updates.
Open the App Store to check for app updates. The Software Update window will not check for updates to your App Store app. You'll need to check for these in the App Store.
- Open the App Store from your dock.
- Click the "Updates" tab.
- Click the "Update" button next to apps with available updates, or "Update All" to download them all at once.'
'0 - Using the Image as an Icon'

1 - Find the icon you want to change.
Find the icon you want to change. Go to the folder that contains the file you'd like to alter. If you want to change an icon on your dock, Control-click and select Options → Show in Finder.
- You can change the icon of most folders, applications, and documents.
- Certain special icons cannot be changed this way, including the Finder and Trash icons. You can change them with the system folder method, or using downloadable software such as LiteIcon (or Candybar for older OS X versions).[3]
- X
- Research source

'2 - Open the information window for that file.\nOpen the information window for that file. Select the file by clicking on its name or image. Control-click the file and select Get Info from the drop-down menu. A new window should open with information about that file.\n- You can also open this window with the hotkey ⌘ Command+i, or the File → Get Info option in the top menu.'
'3 - Select the image in the top left.\nSelect the image in the top left. The file icon is in the top left corner of this window. Click it to select it, and you should see it highlighted in blue.'

'4 - Paste your copied image.\nPaste your copied image. Paste the image you copied with the hotkey ⌘ Command + V, or the Edit → Paste command in the top menu. This should change the file icon to the image you copied earlier.\n- This will only change the icon for that specific file, not for all files of that type.'

'5 - Troubleshoot.
Troubleshoot. If a window pops up asking for a password, you are trying to change a file you do not have full access to. These files can only have their icons changed if you enter an administrator password, or if you log on to an account with access.
- If you think your account should have access, expand the "Sharing and Permissions" section at the bottom of the Get Info window. Change your account name's permission setting to "Read&Write."
- If that still doesn't work, try copy-pasting a second time, or restart your computer.'

'0 - Upgrade to Mountain Lion Online'

'1 - Start the download.\nStart the download. Open the Mac App Store. Click on the Mountain Lion button, or search for "Mountain Lion". Click the price button in the upper left corner of the page. The cost of Mountain Lion is $19.99. After clicking the button, it will change to a green color and read "Buy App." Click on this "Buy" button.\n- You will be prompted to sign in to the App Store, and then to authorize your purchase.'

'2 - Wait.\nWait. Monitor the downloading progress from the "Purchases" tab of the app store. It has to be fully downloaded in order to install, and this can take quite some time depending on your internet speed. After downloading fully, Mountain Lion installer will open in a new window.\n- You can minimize the app store while you wait and it will will continue downloading in the background.'

'3 - Finish the download.\nFinish the download. When the installer is done downloading, an installer window will open. When the Mountain Lion installer window opens, click "continue". Read the new license agreement and click "Agree". After which another dialog box will open, click "Agree" again. This will take you to another screen, where you will click "Install".\n- By default, Mountain Lion installer will install on your current startup drive. If you want to install elsewhere, click the "Show All Disks" button, and select the target drive before clicking "Install".'
'4 - Give credentials.\nGive credentials. You will then be prompted to enter your computer login information, including its password. Do so.'

'5 - Wait.\nWait. The installation process can take 20 minutes, so be patient. When installation is complete your computer will automatically restart.\n- While you are waiting, take the time to make sure all applications are closed because your computer will need to restart when done installing.'
'6 - Done.\nDone. When you computer resumes, you will be running Mountain Lion (OS X 10.8).'

column4: '3 - Finish the download.\nFinish the download. When the installer is done downloading, an installer window will open. When the Mountain Lion installer window opens, click "continue". Read the new license agreement and click "Agree". After which another dialog box will open, click "Agree" again. This will take you to another screen, where you will click "Install".\n- By default, Mountain Lion installer will install on your current startup drive. If you want to install elsewhere, click the "Show All Disks" button, and select the target drive before clicking "Install".'

column1: 'Were settings of show all disk changed?'
column4: '4 - Give credentials.\nGive credentials. You will then be prompted to enter your computer login information, including its password. Do so.'

column1: 'Were settings of show all disk changed?'
column4: '5 - Wait.\nWait. The installation process can take 20 minutes, so be patient. When installation is complete your computer will automatically restart.\n- While you are waiting, take the time to make sure all applications are closed because your computer will need to restart when done installing.'

column1: 'Were settings of show all disk changed?'
column4: '6 - Done.\nDone. When you computer resumes, you will be running Mountain Lion (OS X 10.8).'

column1: 'Were settings of select the target drive changed?'
column4: '0 - Upgrade to Mountain Lion Online'

column1: 'Were settings of select the target drive changed?'
column4: '1 - Start the download.\nStart the download. Open the Mac App Store. Click on the Mountain Lion button, or search for "Mountain Lion". Click the price button in the upper left corner of the page. The cost of Mountain Lion is $19.99. After clicking the button, it will change to a green color and read "Buy App." Click on this "Buy" button.\n- You will be prompted to sign in to the App Store, and then to authorize your purchase.'

column1: 'Were settings of select the target drive changed?'
column4: '2 - Wait.\nWait. Monitor the downloading progress from the "Purchases" tab of the app store. It has to be fully downloaded in order to install, and this can take quite some time depending on your internet speed. After downloading fully, Mountain Lion installer will open in a new window.\n- You can minimize the app store while you wait and it will will continue downloading in the background.'

column1: 'Were settings of select the target drive changed?'
column4: '3 - Finish the download.\nFinish the download. When the installer is done downloading, an installer window will open. When the Mountain Lion installer window opens, click "continue". If you want to install elsewhere, click the "Show All Disks" button, and select the target drive before clicking "Install".'

When installation is complete your computer will automatically restart.\n- While you are waiting, take the time to make sure all applications are closed because your computer will need to restart when done installing.'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the menu bar changed?'
column4: '0 - Hiding the Menu Bar'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the menu bar changed?'
column4: '1 - Click the Apple menu.\nClick the Apple menu.\n- ;'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the menu bar changed?'
column4: '2 - Select "System Preferences."\nSelect "System Preferences."'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the menu bar changed?'
column4: '3 - Click the "General" option.\nClick the "General" option. If you don\'t see this, click the "Show All" button first, which looks like 12 dots arranged in a grid pattern at the top of the window.'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the menu bar changed?'
column4: '4 - Check the "Automatically hide and show the menu bar" box.\nCheck the "Automatically hide and show the menu bar" box. This will hide the menu bar when the mouse is not over it.'

column1: 'Were settings of automatically hide and show the menu bar changed?'
column4:
'5 - Move your mouse to the top of the screen.
Move your mouse to the top of the screen. This will reveal the menu bar.[1]
- X
- Research source'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '0 - Setting Up the Wireless Network'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '1 - Open the Finder  on your Mac.\nOpen the Finder  on your Mac.  The Finder is the app that has a blue and white image with a smiley face.  The Finder is used to browse files and applications on your Mac.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 2 - Click Applications.\nClick Applications.  It's in the sidebar to the left in the Finder.  This will display all the applications installed on your Mac.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 3 - Double-click the Utilities folder.\nDouble-click the Utilities folder. It's the blue folder with the icon of a wrench and screwdriver on it at the bottom of the page.  This is where all your Mac's system applications are stored.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 4 - Double-click AirPort Utility.\nDouble-click AirPort Utility.  It's the app with a blue Wi-Fi symbol on a white background. It's located near the top of the page when displayed alphabetically.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 5 - Click Other wireless devices.\nClick Other wireless devices.  It's in the upper-left corner of the AirPort Utility app.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '6 - Click AirPort Time Capsule.\nClick AirPort Time Capsule.  It\'s in the menu for Other wireless devices in AirPort Time Capsule.  You may see six letters and numbers after "AirPort Time Capsule" like "fea88c" or something similar.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '7 - Select Create New Network and click Next.\nSelect Create New Network and click Next.  You will see a list of options when you click on the Time Capsule in AirPort Utility.  Click the radial button next to "Create New Network" at the top of the list of options.  Click "Next" when you are done.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '8 - Name the network.\nName the network.  Click the text box next to "Network Name" and type a name for the network.  You can name the network anything you want.  You can name it your last name, or something clever.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '9 - Name the base station.\nName the base station.  Click the box next to "Base Station Name" and type a name.  The base station is the name for the Time Capsule.  Having a separate name for the Time Capsule is useful if you ever get another Time Capsule to expand your network.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '10 - Create a password.\nCreate a password.  Use the text boxes next to "Network Password" and "Verify Password" to create a password.  Make sure the password is identical for both boxes.\n- To create a separate password for the Time Capsule, uncheck "Use a single password"  This will give you two more boxes to create a password for the individual Time Capsule.  This is useful if you have more than one Time Capsule and you want to create a password for a guest house or guest room.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 11 - Click Next.\nClick Next.  It's in the lower-right corner of the AirPort Utility app.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '12 - Restart your modem.\nRestart your modem.  Now you will be asked to reboot your modem.  Unplug it for about a minute and plug it back in and wait for it to fully restart.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '13 - Create a guest network (optional).\nCreate a guest network (optional).  If you wish to enable a guest network, check the checkbox next to "Enable guest network" and then type a name for the guest network.  This allows guests to be able to access your network without being able to access all the computers on the network.  If you don\'t want to have a guest network, don\'t click the checkbox.'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 14 - Click Next.\nClick Next.  It's in the lower-right corner of the AirPort Utility app.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '15 - Enable diagnostics & usage data to be sent to Apple (optional).\nEnable diagnostics & usage data to be sent to Apple (optional).  If you want your Time Capsule to send diagnostics and usage data to Apple, click the radial button next to "Send diagnostics & usage data to Apple".  All data sent to Apple is anonymous.  If you don\'t wish to send diagnostics and usage data to Apple, click the radial button next to "Don\'t Send".'

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: 16 - Click Next.\nClick Next.  It's in the lower-right corner of the AirPort Utility app.  AirPort Utility will now configure your network.

column1: 'Were settings of air port time capsule changed?'
column4: '17 - Click Done.\nClick Done.  You network setup is now complete.'

'0 - Mac OS X 10.4 or 10.5 - Setup as Server'
'1 - Open your System Preferences from your blue apple menu.\nOpen your System Preferences from your blue apple menu.'
2 - Click the Sharing icon under the 'Internet and Network' category.\nClick the Sharing icon under the 'Internet and Network' category.
'3 - Highlight the Apple Remote Desktop component in the list of items.\nHighlight the Apple Remote Desktop component in the list of items.'
'4 - Click Start to fire up Apple Remote Desktop service.\nClick Start to fire up Apple Remote Desktop service.'

'5 - If you are NOT connecting with JollysFastVNC or ScreenSharing you need the following steps:
If you are NOT connecting with JollysFastVNC or ScreenSharing you need the following steps:
- Click Access Privileges to open the more advanced options.
- Check on VNC viewers may control screen with password and define a password.'
6 - You can close the System Preferences.\nYou can close the System Preferences. You're done!

'0 - Mac OS X 10.5 - iChat Method'
'1 - Open iChat using a .Mac account or Bonjour if both computers are on the same network.\nOpen iChat using a .Mac account or Bonjour if both computers are on the same network.'
'2 - Select your buddy in the main buddies list.\nSelect your buddy in the main buddies list.'

'3 - At the bottom of iChat is a Screen Sharing button that looks like two squares one over the other.\nAt the bottom of iChat is a Screen Sharing button that looks like two squares one over the other.'
4 - Select either Share My Screen With <buddy> or Ask to Share <buddy>'s Screen.\nSelect either Share My Screen With <buddy> or Ask to Share <buddy>'s Screen.
'5 - iChat takes care of the rest.\niChat takes care of the rest.\n- To end the session press [Command]+[Esc] on either computer.'
